debate.title: STATES GRANTS (PRIMARY AND SECONDARY EDUCATION ASSISTANCE) BILL 1996

talk.start.para: —The committee is considering the bill as a whole and Senator Bolkus's amendments Nos 1 and 13. The question is that the amendments be agreed to.

—Minister, on Wednesday you told the Senate several times that it was not reasonable for the Commonwealth to continue to pay the states for students who had moved out of government schools. This was the basis of your plan to apply the enrolment benchmark adjustment. Is it not true that the Commonwealth recurrent moneys for schools are already paid on a per capita basis and, therefore, money already follows the student?

speech.ministerial: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs
speech.speaker: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

talker.name: Senator VANSTONE
talker.role: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

talk.start.para:
—Senator, I honestly believe that this matter has been canvassed again and again. We can continue to raise it. As you well understand, the EBA is designed to reflect a shift in students. You can, of course, focus on existing numbers of one portion—in your case, you choose to
focus on the existing numbers in government schools—and disregard all population coming in. You can say, `If it follows the student, it should stay the same.' One wise man would say that—nonetheless, I have yet to find a wise man who does.

speech.para: Another wise man would say, `What is important about this is where the people are choosing to send their children.' Therefore, one does not look at today's student numbers for next year, the year after or the year after that; one looks at where the students in those years are going. On that basis, one obviously looks at where the new students coming in go to or, for that matter, where students in the existing population shift to. The EBA is designed to reflect that. Consequently, if there is a change in the proportion, that is, if students move as a whole, the EBA would be triggered. That is what it is designed to reflect.

Senator, you understand how this works, Senator Allison understands how this works. We can keep repeating this, but it is exactly as I have related it to you. You, Senator Allison, the Australian Democrats and Labor would have it that if numbers stay the same in three, four, five, six or seven years time the money would be the same. This is an indicator, a reflection of a shift in the proportion of students, if not taking all the money from the states that they save by students shifting into the non-government sector. It is, in fact, splitting that saving with them. We think that is perfectly fair.
I understand, Senator, that you have a different view and the Democrats have a different view. I have made that point in here before. We have a difference of policy here.

talk.start.para: —A change of government.

—As Senator Patterson interjects, we have had a change of government. It is no surprise that we have had a change of policy. But it is no surprise, even without a change of government, that we would have differences of opinion. No amount of debate is going to change those opinions. There are times when something is such that people do not understand it, and debate will often help then.

break.para: I participated in a debate in this chamber earlier this year when there was a genuine misunderstanding as to the consequence of a particular matter. As a consequence of a genuine debate, where people were genuinely exchanging different views and arguing to a particular point, a bill was changed for the better. That was not because there was a difference of policy; it was because both sides of the chamber recognised what needed to be protected and were simply canvassing views about the best way to protect that. It related to one of the Attorney-General's bills. That is completely different. Here we have a difference of policy. You have different views from us and you are not going to agree. I accept that.

speech.speaker: Carr, Sen Kim

talk.start.para: —Minister, I put it to you that this is not just a question of a difference of policy. It is quite clear that there is a substantial difference in policy. I acknowledge that. I would be horrified to think otherwise, given the nature of the differences of our political philosophies. But this is not the issue of substance in question here. I am trying to get at what is the mechanism by which this government seeks to achieve its policy.

speech.para: I say that this policy is wrong, and I make it very clear that I do not run away from that statement. But I also say that this policy will have unintended consequences, one would have to presume, given your statements. The effect of these changes is to shift costs from the Commonwealth to the states and to take money away from the states in a manner which this parliament has not designated in a conscious form. It is one thing for you to come into the parliament and say, `I wish to take $1.5 billion out of the financial assistance grants.' You made that statement very clear in terms of the government, and the parliament makes a decision about that.

But it is another thing to come in here and say, `We're seeking to achieve these savings in a manner which the states will then be able to administer in a certain way.' The point of these questions is to show to you, and hopefully the other senators in this chamber, that the consequences of your policies will be to take additional moneys away from the states.
So, rather than there being savings to the states, there will be additional costs to the states.

What does that mean? In Victoria we have already seen very substantial cuts in spending for government schooling, to the tune of some 10 per cent. We have seen some 300 schools close. We have seen a further 113 schools identified for closure this year. We have a minister who actually feels that it is appropriate to go on the public record and suggest that we can do with less schooling for our children in that state, that those children can do more for their education by staying away from school, by staying at home, which was what he suggested just this week, and that we can therefore do with fewer teachers, fewer schools and fewer resources in education.

I am worried that a proposition such as this will play right into that sort of minister's hands. When he is faced with the prospect of further cuts of between $20 million and $30 million for every two per cent shift in the enrolment benchmark adjustment as a result of these policies, I am concerned that a minister like that—Minister Gude, who essentially is an educational philistine—will be able to say, `The Commonwealth parliament has told us to do this in this manner.' Of course, Minister, it is all very well, when the children of the next generation have this cruel experiment inflicted upon them, to say, `We didn't mean it that way.'

That is why it is important for these measures to be thoroughly examined and for the senators to understand what the implications of this action are. I just do not accept the proposition that you are putting—that there are in fact savings. You claim that the states have access to these savings and that when students move from government to non-government schools the so-called saving is some $3,400. It is not some additional beneficial payment provided by the Commonwealth, as you continually imply.

speech.ministerial: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs
speech.speaker: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

talker.name: Senator VANSTONE
talker.role: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

talk.start.para:
—I think, by the contribution you have made, that you have in fact highlighted the point that I made. I appreciate that we found something that we
agree on—that we do have a disagreement. Maybe we can agree on more than that on another day, but at least today we have made that clear: you have a different philosophical approach to this from ours. You say that you would be horrified if it were the same. I would not be. I think there are many occasions in policy areas, including some in education, where the philosophies are the same. I would not exaggerate it to the point of saying that we are always going to disagree. But, on this, clearly we do. Clearly, the purpose of these debates is to give people the opportunity to outline their particular views and to persuade other senators.

speech.para: I have put the government's view to you—that the important thing for you to recognise, in our view, in consideration of what you want to do in this matter, is that we have set up this EBA, which is a mechanism designed to reflect shifts in students. We think that is appropriate; you do not. I have also asked you to consider that on our calculations—rough as they might be, but I do not think they are going to be far off—the EBA, that you seek to spend so much time on discussing, roughly works out at just over three per cent of SPPs. If you include the total funding for schools—that is, SPPs and FAGs—you will find that it is less than one per cent. That is what we are talking about in relation to the disagreement.

I understand that you further say in effect that you do not trust the states or, in particular, you do not trust the state of Victoria; maybe the whole lot. You expect this is an insecure path to go down because the states will not necessarily do the right thing. I just repeat what I have indicated to you in the past: on preliminary estimates made by the department, using documents available from state governments, the best information we have is that there is going to be an increase in expenditure on education by the states.

You may disagree with that. You may have some inside knowledge or a different view of how the figures add up. But the opportunity provided here is for you to convince, in this case, if you do not want this bill to be passed, Senator Harradine and the Australian Democrats—although I suspect they have made up their minds; I certainly gather they have, from
what Senator Allison says—the two Greens and Senator Colston.

The government is not going to change its mind on this. We think we are on the right track. We think we have made the appropriate policy change, and it is, as I say, relatively small. I thought Senator Allison was a little bit ungracious in saying that I say that it is nothing. I do not say that it is nothing at all. But I do say that it is relatively small—on our calculations, just over three per cent if you look at it in terms of the SPPs and less than one per cent if you look at it in total, SPPs and FAGs. You disagree with that, but this is your opportunity to convince other senators.

talk.start.para: —I ask again: is it not the case that, because the Commonwealth moneys under the present administrative arrangements are funded on a per capita basis for recurrent moneys, the money already follows the students? There are current arrangements in place under your terms. Further, is it not a reality that what this is about is saving the Commonwealth money—not providing choice, not providing greater flexibility, but saving the Commonwealth money?

speech.ministerial: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs
speech.speaker: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

talker.name: Senator VANSTONE
talker.role: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

talk.start.para: —Senator, you understand, I understand and everyone understands what per capita funding is. That is why I was very grateful that you agreed to put on the amendments to the then Aboriginal education special initiatives program legislation, now referred to as the indigenous education special initiatives program legislation. I remember going over to you to thank you very much for doing that, because we have shifted to per capita funding and I thought that that was very important. Just as an aside, yesterday we signed the first agreement with a school, the Yiyili Aboriginal Community School—I am not sure how you pronounce that—in northern Western Australia.

speech.para:
We all understand what per capita funding means, that more students mean more money, fewer students mean less money. That is in the SPP. What you are not looking at is the FAGs, and you are also not taking account of the cost shifting the states are engaging in.
That is what you are, in a sense, seeking to ignore. We believe that by implementing an EBA there is an incentive for the state governments to recognise the cost shifting they have been engaging in and to do what they can to ensure that the shift that is happening as a consequence of parental choice does not continue. We are not running around telling people to shift their kids into private schools. It is a function of parental choice.

talk.start.para: —But by making the schools smaller you are promoting it.

—Senator, your party was in government for 13 years, and it is previous governments' policies that have encouraged parents to make the choice they have made. Parents have looked at schools and how they have ended up as a consequence of previous government policies—I accept not just federal government but state government as well—and they have made choices. This is not a sudden choice parents are making as a consequence of a change in government in March. It is not that at all. People were already making that choice.

speech.para: Senator Neal's party would seek to say that we can ignore that. We do not think we can. We think we have to recognise there is some cost shifting here, that parents are making these choices and that there have to be changes as a consequence. The changes are small—as I have indicated, on the calculations we have, around three per cent of SPPs and only one per cent if we look at the total funding. We do not think people can say this is a significant change which is a disaster. It is not a disaster at all. It is a very sensible recognition. It is a small change, yes, but significant in the sense that it is a recognition, we believe, of the cost shifting that has been going on. We think it is an appropriate change to make.

I accept that Senator Neal's party does not think that. We have a difference of opinion. We believe that the cost shifting is inappropriate and we need a mechanism that properly reflects the choices that parents are making—and there has been this choice. I cannot easily articulate for the chamber in one or two sentences why parents have apparently been making these choices. Perhaps Senator Carr
might like to indicate why he thinks parents have been making these choices, why so many people from the Labor Party send their kids to private schools and why so many people in the Australian Democrats either taught at or went to private schools. That is a matter of parental choice, and there would be different reasons on all occasions.

talk.start.para: —Some people have to.

—As Senator Panizza says, some have to. Some people who live in the country may want their kids to go to a city school and, rather than have them boarding privately with a family, they send them to a boarding school. There are all sorts of different reasons.

speech.para: We think the new schools policy as established by the previous government was harsh. We think it is wrong that people who so desperately want to make a different choice for their children in education send them to a school that does not have Commonwealth funding because the new schools policy will not allow it. We think that is wrong. We think we have to be responsive to what parents want—not dictatorial about but responsive to what they want. We think it is wrong there are schools like that. That is why we want to get rid of the new schools policy.

We think governments, not just federal but state as well, should be responsive to choices parents want to make. Of course there are some basics in education where state and federal governments have to draw the line, but the choices parents want to make about where they send their kids to school and what it is they think is important that their kids get in primary and second schooling are not things we should be, in a monetary sense, trying to limit with a policy like the previous government's new schools policy.

When we came into government we looked at the situation and found people are making this choice, that they are wanting to shift their children to private schools, non-government schools. Senator Neal, Senator Carr and Senator Allison might be able to tell me—I would like to hear these words from Senator Allison's mouth—why it is that parents are making these choices, why the federal government should simply ignore this trend and why
it is we should ignore the cost shifting by the states. Why should the federal government allow the states to engage in this cost shifting and not make a change?

These are the arguments I would like to hear. I understand there is a difference of opinion in a policy sense and that senators opposite will be critical of what the government wants to do. But what I would like to hear are reasons why we should ignore parental choice and why this has happened. Senators opposite seem to have a view that this government is somehow opposed to government schools. That is not right at all. It is not us making the choices about where children go. It is the parents.

I would be very happy to hear some views about that from members opposite—that is, if in fact we have the time. The bottom line is that we are nearing the end of the session, we have a number of bills before us and it is simply a case of deciding whether we do or do not agree with this. Perhaps I am being irresponsible in inviting those opposite to give me those comments. Perhaps we could discuss it over a couple of Christmas drinks. I am just trying to indicate the position I am coming from—that I do not understand why you have this view. But I accept that you do, that you are not going to change your mind and that you are going to vote against this.

speech.speaker: Allison, Sen Lyn

talk.start.para: —It is true that there is a difference in policy. However, much of this bill depends on the arguments that the government has put so far about the difference this will make, particularly to government schools. It is very important that we clarify a couple of points.

speech.para: I would like to put a statement to you and ask you to tell me whether this is right or wrong. The enrolment benchmark adjustment deducts from state schools' budgets $1,712 for each new student in the private sector over the current enrolment proportion and, on the government's own projections, this sum is $305 million over four years. Minister, I think we can almost finish this debate about the enrolment benchmark adjustment if you can clarify whether or not that is a correct statement. I will go through it again if you need me to.

speech.ministerial: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs
speech.speaker: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

talker.name: Senator VANSTONE
talker.role: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

talk.start.para: —On the projections I think you are referring to, Senator, you would understand that without an enrolment benchmark adjustment, the states would save about $3,400 every time someone shifted over. I understand that your preference is that we allow them to do that. Our preference is that we do not—that we split the difference and take half of that, which is about $1,700.

—I am sorry, but that is not an answer to my question. It does not indicate whether this calculation is correct or not. I would ask you to address that question. I will say it again: the EBA deducts from the state schools' budget $1,712.50, on average, for each new student in the private sector over the current enrolment proportion and, on the government's own projections, this sum is $305 million over four years.

speech.ministerial: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs
speech.speaker: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

talker.name: Senator VANSTONE
talker.role: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

talk.start.para: —Senator, you have asked this question in various formats on numerous occasions, including the other day. I believe it was Wednesday; it might have been another day. I have answered you again today and I have nothing further to add.

speech.speaker: Allison, Sen Lyn

talk.start.para: —I can only conclude from that that the government is unwilling to admit that that is the effect of the enrolment benchmark adjustment. I can only come to that conclusion because, as you have rightly pointed out, I have asked this question of you several times. I have used the government's own projections; I have not made up any of these figures. That is the conclusion that I draw. Each time you answer this question, you do not answer the question. I ask the rest of the Senate to assume that it is correct and that it is a question you do not wish to answer because it does show that the effect of this bill is to take very large amounts of money from the government sector.

speech.para:
I will ask you the next question. The EBA does not deduct $1,712.50 for each student who transfers from a state to a private school—that is, the EBA does not work in the
way that you might have said in the past. It does not deduct that amount of money for each student who actually transfers from a state to a private school. That is not the way the EBA is working. That is my question to you. I will say it again: the EBA does not deduct $1,712 for each student who transfers from a state school to a private school. Is that correct or not?

speech.ministerial: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs
speech.speaker: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

talker.name: Senator VANSTONE
talker.role: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

talk.start.para: —Senator, you are back on to the same issue, and you know you are. It is a function of the proportion that has been indicated to you before. I simply indicate it to you again.

—Once again, I can assume that that statement is correct. My third statement is as follows: even if the state schools system maintains its enrolment numbers, the EBA would still remove funds of around $270 million from the Commonwealth recurrent grants to the states, or the SPPs. Is that or is that not a correct statement?

speech.ministerial: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs
speech.speaker: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

talker.name: Senator VANSTONE
talker.role: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

talk.start.para: —Senator, this is a question that you asked the other day. At vast expense, we are happy to sit here and answer it again for you. You understand quite well how the EBA works. You understand that the question you have put is premised on the assumption, maybe only for the purposes of debate, that any increase in enrolment from schools would all go to non-government schools, which you and I know is incorrect.

speech.para:
You understand that the EBA works through the SPP and you refuse to acknowledge the combination of SPPs and FAGs as funding to the states for schools. You do not accept that as an appropriate means of describing the amount of money going to the states on children. You want to focus just on this EBA—this thing that is about three per cent of SPPs and one per cent of FAGs and SPPs put together—because you think that is important. Of course, every aspect of policy is important. These questions have all been answered for you before. You can keep
asking them but the answers are not going to change.

speech.speaker: Allison, Sen Lyn

talk.start.para: —I am beginning to realise that, Minister. The answer is going to be that there is no answer because I think you are acknowledging, by your reluctance to say, `No, that is wrong', that it is right.

speech.para: I would like to remind you about what you said on 29 October. You said:

There will not be any change to funding for government schools if the government sector can continue to maintain its enrolments. That is the key to it all. The money, in a sense, will follow the students.

I put it to you, Minister, that that is, at best, misleading. Given that you will not deny the three statements that I suggested earlier, that is completely misleading and incorrect. This is the message that you have been putting out to Australians—to the parents of 70 per cent of Australian children who send their children to a government school.

This is the crux of the debate. You might argue that it is insignificant, but it is, nevertheless, the crux of the debate. I ask you now: do you stand by that statement that there will not be any change to funding for government schools if the government sector can continue to maintain its enrolments?

talk.start.para: —Perhaps, Senator, you would like to read the rest of what you quoted in your first question. You went further than that.
—Yes, I am happy to do that. You also said:

speech.para: That is the key to it all. The money, in a sense, will follow the students.

Minister, perhaps you could tell us what you mean by `the money, in a sense, will follow the students'. It will not follow the students or it partly follows the students? Perhaps you can clarify that part of it. But I still think it is important that you address that first statement:
There will not be any change to funding for government schools if the government sector can continue to maintain its enrolments.

speech.ministerial: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs
speech.speaker: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

talker.name: Senator VANSTONE
talker.role:
Minister for Employment, Education, Training
and Youth Affairs)

talk.start.para: —Senator, you have participated in a number of committee hearings and people have indulged you—I should not say `indulged you' because it is your job to get to the bottom of what the government wants to do. But you are now repeating questions ad infinitum and, as I have indicated to you, you will get the same answers.

speech.para: On the question of misleading, I have heard on various other occasions you touting this view around that that is misleading. I do not think it is, which is why I asked you to repeat it. What I said was:
The money, in a sense, will follow the students.
You were hoping that I would have said that the money follows each individual student. That is what you would like me to have said.

You know what `in a sense' is; it is a qualifier. You understand the sense in which it follows students and that is the proportions. If you have the confidence that you should have in government schools because, as I understand it, you were a teacher, presumably, in a government school—I am not sure; is that correct? Have I got the right end of the stick there?

speech.speaker: Allison, Sen Lyn

talk.start.para:
—When I graduated from college, I was told by the government that there would be no further jobs available in the government sector and I chose then to work in the Catholic sector. The reason there were no jobs for teachers when I graduated was that my state government, the Victorian government, was cutting jobs for teachers.
So those who were graduating had no option but to move into the private sector.

speech.para: But I would have been glad to have taught in either sector. I would have been quite happy to have taught in the state sector. I went to school in the state sector and that is, I suppose, where my support for education lies.

talk.start.para: —I got it wrong, Senator, I am sorry. I would be interested to know, though, under which government you graduated.

—Before I call Senator Carr, may I remind the Senate that the ques
tion before the chair is that amendments Nos 1 and 13 be agreed to.

speech.speaker: Carr, Sen Kim

talk.start.para: —Minister, if I could return to this proposition of the so-called money following the student. I make the point that this EBA is a device of your government's creation and it is predicated upon a presumption that there are savings to be made as a result of students moving from one sector to another.

speech.para: I think Senator Allison has clearly demonstrated—and Labor senators demonstrated this on Wednesday—that there may be a situation where there will necessarily be no savings to the states and that the number of government students may remain the same and they will lose money under this proposal. This is a device by which the government is the one that saves the money. It is a cost shifting device by the Commonwealth to the states. Minister, you say that there are savings there, but every state disputes your claim.

talk.start.para: —Of course they do.
—`Of course they do'. That is just far too glib a proposition. The people who run the largest school system in the country in New South Wales said:

speech.para: You will only ever see marginal changes in classroom numbers.
Do you dispute that? The New South Wales officials also told us:

Also, you will generally only see changes in the number of students in a particular class—one, two, three or four, depending on the school. You will not see whole schools disappear; you will not see whole subject areas disappear.

Therefore, to take all the school system, including the administrative and executive structures of the schools as well as the state infrastructure . . . as being deleted or changed in any way is a nonsense. You will only see the change at the margin. Therefore, the DEET analysis is substantially flawed.
Why is that wrong minister?

speech.ministerial: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs
speech.speaker: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

talker.name: Senator VANSTONE
talker.role: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

talk.start.para: —We are debating at the moment amendments dealing with the enrolment benchmark adjustment. We had a quite extensive debate on this earlier in the week.

break.para: The government has made its position very clear with respect to the enrolment benchmark adjustment. We will be giving more money to government schools, counting the SPPs and FAGs together. The per capita increase is higher for government schools than for non‐government schools. On that basis, we think any claim that we are opposed to government schools is just patently false. Anyone who looks at the dollars can see that.

As you rightly identify, Senator Carr, and as we openly say, we have introduced this enrolment benchmark adjustment mechanism, EBA, because we believe the states are cost shifting to the Commonwealth and that cost shifting needs to be addressed. We are splitting the savings that the states are making when students shift into non‐government schools and we think that is appropriate.

I just want to emphasise that this whole debate, which took place some time earlier in the week and which we are now repeating, relates to less than one per cent, we believe, of total funding for schools when you look at SPPs and FAGs. That is the area of the adjustment we are looking at making, if enrolments continue as they are.

speech.speaker: Carr, Sen Kim

talk.start.para: —The proposition that you are advancing is predicated on a presumption—I stress, a presumption—that the enrolment benchmark adjustment is based on this notion of average costs. The New South Wales officials say that this approach is incorrect and unsound. They are supported by every government in the Commonwealth. Every state government says that.

speech.para: The costs included in the average costs incorporate school executive funding, staff development funding, school administrative funding, general school running costs and all non‐school based administration, as well as the costs of providing teachers.

All of the states contend that the Commonwealth cannot and must not use average costs as the basis for calculating cost savings to the states where students transfer to the non-government sector. What they are saying is that the costs relating to non-school based administration, school executive staffing, school administration and general school
running costs, such as utility funding, will not be affected, nor will they be reduced, under the scenarios you are putting to the committee. Therefore, they conclude that only marginal costs based on pupil-teacher ratios can be taken into account.

Why is it, minister, that your officials have told the Senate time and time again that they have not got a clue as to what is happening in the schools across this country, in response to repeated questioning from me on the operations of the targeted assistance programs and quality assurance programs? They have said time and time again that they cannot tell us how the money is spent for the disadvantaged schools program. They cannot tell us how the money is actually spent at the school level for the country area program or for disabilities. They cannot tell us because they do not have the systems in place. Why is it, minister, that you are now saying that your officials know better about the operation and administration of schools than the people who actually have the hands-on experience of the largest school system in the country, which is supported by every other school administration in the country?

speech.ministerial: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs
speech.speaker: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

talker.name: Senator VANSTONE
talker.role: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

talk.start.para: —The New South Wales comments were raised during submissions to the committee. The department responded to that in its submission. You raised those comments by New South Wales in the debate we had earlier this week. I went through, in part, the departmental response it had prepared and referred you again to that submission, as I do now.

speech.para: I simply want to add that you indicate a dissatisfaction with looking at an average. You may—I put it no higher than `may'; you may want to underline it because some people are wont to fail to see the distinction between `may' and `shall'—have had a point if one was looking at an average and then saying, `We'll take the lot.' But since it is 50 per cent, I do not think you have a complaint.

speech.speaker: Allison, Sen Lyn

talk.start.para:
—I understand why the government does not want to focus on the EBA, and I am sure we will be able to move off that shortly. You
said that it was insignificant, and I am glad that you corrected that calculation. It is not one per cent; it is three per cent. The effect of the EBA—this has been verified by the department—will be to cost every student remaining in state schools $140 over the four-year period. That is in fact not one per cent or three per cent. To those students, that represents an eight per cent cut in recurrent grants. I need to say that there is in fact very little that is new in terms of extra money for programs in this budget. It is something that you claim, nevertheless.

speech.para: Possibly, the government is resting on its additional $145 million for literacy in making these claims. This additional $145 million for literacy represents just $14 per student over three years, or $4.66 per student per year. I am drawing on those figures just to get the EBA into perspective. We are talking here about $140 per student remaining in government schools, compared with what you make a great deal about: the $4.66 per student per year for literacy, for instance.

I think it is important that senators understand the effect of the EBA out there in the real world. I want you to understand that this mechanism means that, even if state schools maintain their numbers, their share of enrolments decreases, they will lose money under the mechanism. I think we have made that pretty clear this morning. It is not a policy difference and it is not an academic debate. This is about the very simple fact that, even if the numbers of real children in real state schools stay the same, those schools still lose money.

To assist senators to understand what is going on out there in the real world, I thought I would bring in some of the many hundreds of letters that I have received from schools. This one is from Ogilvie High School, in New Town Tasmania. The letter states, in part:

Government schools, particularly within Tasmania, are operating with budgets that provide minimal allowance for expenditure on the wide range of material and expertise needed to equip our students for a rapidly changing world. It is only through good management, extensive fundraising and in many cases good fortune that public schools are surviving at the present time. Any proposal that
decreases general funding to the state system is potentially catastrophic.

talk.start.para: —What percentage of student leavers from Ogilvie go on to state matric?
—I will go on with the rest of the letter, Senator. It does not actually give those figures, but I am happy—
—How many of them go to independent schools after they have been to Ogilvie?
—Perhaps I can just continue with the letter and let you know. The chairman of the council says:

speech.para: In closing I would like to point out that it is possible to provide the highest quality education within the state system as clearly demonstrated by the record of the school for which I am privileged to be School Council Chairman. Ogilvie High School has a current enrolment of some 950 pupils. The 1997 Grade 7 intake will be around 290 with more than 350 prospective grade 7 students being turned away.
Ogilvie High School students consistently perform above average in science, mathematics, literacy and the arts with an outstanding record in comparison to both private and public schools.

Although highly successful and regarded as such by the community, as evidenced by the number of students wishing to attend the school, there has been little major assistance from government in recent history to alleviate serious accommodation problems. A major upgrade of antiquated science laboratories, planned to commence in 1996/97, has been shelved indefinitely due to lack of finance within the government system.
A letter from the Northcote High School in my home state of Victoria states:

Our Council believes that students in Government Schools need to retain all of their funding to equip and support their operations which generally trail behind the level of resourcing applying in independent schools. Our Council urges you to do all you can to stop this Bill being passed.
A letter from Bundoora Primary School states:
We are struggling on the budget we currently have, stretching the money and our creativity to the limit in our efforts to provide the best possible education for our children.
A letter from Eureka Public School in New South Wales states:

This blatant attempt to bolster the non government school sector by targeting the money aimed for the
state schools is another indication that soon degree of wealth will dictate degree of education.

Public schools are already under‐funded. To restrict funding further would serve to totally undermine an already struggling system. Society will certainly pay a terrible price if we continue to tread along this path of complete disregard for the education of our children.
A letter from Runcorn Heights State School states:

To take more money away from state schools is simply absurd. Our P.&C. Association is continually under great pressure to raise money to make up the shortfall when Government grants money does not cover all it is meant to cover. Our school population stems from middle to lower class poorer families who are not always able to contribute to fund raising plans and so our children are the ones who suffer in the long term.

At our school we have over‐crowded classes. At one stage this year we had 32 students in one year one class and 32 in another year one class. Paint is peeling from the buildings and from the walls inside the tuckshop. The student desks and chairs are the ones that were originally supplied when the school was opened twenty one years ago. We are desperately trying to raise the money required to enclose our under covered area so it can be utilised fully.

As a school council we feel there are a lot of other areas that would benefit from this money. Parents who choose to send their children to non government schools pay yearly fees. These non government schools should not be given more funding than government schools particularly if this money is to be taken away from government schools.

That is just a small selection of the numerous pieces of correspondence that have come into my office over the past few weeks. This is why the Democrats are saying that this mechanism is unfair and it is, in fact, dangerous.

During the hearing, I asked DEETYA to prepare a table showing the overall effect of the enrolment benchmark adjustment on the basis of a non-government proportion increase, and there were five different stages: 31.1 per cent, which I understand is projected until the end of the year 2000; 33 per cent; 35 per cent; 40 per cent; and 50 per cent. I seek leave to table a copy of that table.

What this table shows is that at 31.1 per cent we see a per student deduction of $42. If the $406 SPPs to each student were to
remain the same—and this is theoretical, of course, but it does give some indication of the direction that we are talking about with this EBA—at 31.1 per cent, $42 would be deducted from that grant. That would leave $364. At 33 per cent, which is not all that much higher—and if we proceeded, even under the current new schools policy, we would probably expect that to increase over the next three years to 33.3 per cent—we would get a $91 decrease. If it rose to 35 per cent, we would get a $147 decrease. That would bring down that figure to $259. When it reached 40 per cent, we would be looking at a $301 decrease. That would leave $105.

If the figure rose to 50 per cent—I doubt very much that it would, but I asked for this calculation to be done so that we could get some understanding of what this EBA might mean in the longer term, and we have to remember that we do not have any projections beyond the year 2000 for the EBA—with the government sector having 1.5 million students, they would, in fact, be paying back the Commonwealth government at $295 per student. That is the effect of the EBA. It continues to take money out of the states. It continues to punish the states for the enrolments in the private sector.

If we did reach that position—and I am not suggesting we will—we would have a situation where the states would be obliged to pay the Commonwealth government $469 million. That is clearly absurd. I think it is not beyond the realms of possibility that we would reach that 50 per cent. It just shows how unfair and how absurd that whole notion of punishing for policy reasons is: one sector is punished as a result of the increase in another.

The Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs trots out the old familiar story that the states have been cost shifting. We have heard that again this morning. Now a figure of $3 billion is being tossed around, and we understand that goes back to 1983. A 13-year-old piece of mathematics would not seem to me to be all that useful and, of course, it is not substantiated like most other claims of this nature. There is no explanation either. We are, nevertheless, told that we have to accept that the states have
been doing all this cost shifting. I am not sure where the money has gone. It certainly has not gone to education as those letters, which I have already quoted from, point out.

This is probably about as relevant to today's debate as the $2.3 billion extra which the government says is being spent over the next four years. I refer to the tables in the report of the committee. There are two tables. There is one prepared by the department on page 14 and there is another on page 67, which has more or less the same figures but which has some calculations that draw upon those figures. Compared with spending in 1996, these figures on page 14—the calculations are not done for us, unfortunately, but I am happy to expand on them, because I have done the adding up myself—show that there is a budget increase of $96 million for government schools and $530 million for private schools in additional funds over the next four years.

I seek clarification, or at least acknowledgment, from the department that this is the case. All I have done is take the year 2000 in the last column and compared that with 1996, which I gather is what the government wants us to do in calculating their additional funding. I have also looked at the same figure for non-government schools. Compared with spending in 1996, the specific purpose payments show a budget increase of $96 million for government schools and $530 million for private schools over the next four years. This adds up to an increase for both sectors of $626 million. My question to the minister and the department is this: if it is $626 million, and they are your figures, where does the $2.3 billion come from?

speech.ministerial: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs
speech.speaker: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

talker.name: Senator VANSTONE
talker.role: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

talk.start.para:
—I thank the senator for what in effect is pretty much a repeat of a speech on the second reading debate and a repeat of questions that were asked in the committee and in this debate the other day. I want to say more strongly than I did before that this is the committee stage of the bill. This is where we are meant to get things right. With respect, we are looking at amendments moved by the opposition, which
I understand Senator Allison wants to support. Quite appropriately, we have paid some attention to them. I suspect, with the greatest respect, that you have made a mistake in one of your amendments. I am happy to point it out to you.

speech.para: I think we should move on. This is the committee stage, where we are looking at amendments to the bill. I ask you to look at amendment No. 1. I ask members opposite to shift the focus from what was hashed out in the committee and debated here the other day. We have done all that. Let us move on to the business of the Senate, which is the amendments that the opposition has moved, particularly amendment No. 1.

I simply raise this because, if you are going to move these amendments, we may as well understand what you are on about. As I understand it, what you are seeking to do via amendment No. 1 is to stop the Commonwealth having the capacity to take money back vis-a-vis government schools, in which case I suspect that you should have had division 1 written in the place where you now have division 2 written. If that is the case, you might want to change it. I saw Senator Carr nodding his head. I think that is what he is intending to do with amendment No. 1.

talk.start.para: —We will double check that.
—That is fine. While he is doing that, perhaps Senator Allison would like to comment on whether it should be division 1 or 2.

—While we are waiting for Senator Carr to comment, I am wondering why the minister is so reluctant to answer this question. It is a straightforward question. You say $2.3 billion. The figures here clearly show $96 million and $530 million. There is a big difference between the two. While we are waiting for Senator Carr's response, perhaps the minister could answer the question.

speech.ministerial: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs
speech.speaker: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

talker.name: Senator VANSTONE
talker.role: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

talk.start.para:
—With respect, Senator Allison been given this answer on so many occasions. She has asked it in the Senate in question time and on other occa
sions. The way that the government has come to those calculations has been clearly indicated. It involves the SPPs and FAGs. If you are presumably supporting this amendment, do you think it should be division 1 or 2 in opposition amendment No. 1, or are you not focusing on the detail?

—I have not asked this question before because I only did the calculation last night. I had accepted that the $2.3 billion was an increase until I did that calculation. It is pertinent. I come back to the government's arguments that all of this EBA is insignificant because there is such a large increase of $2.3 billion. Why is anyone worrying, when we are talking about such large increases. It is highly relevant. It is not an old question. I did not calculate it until just yesterday. I would be happy if you answered that question.

speech.speaker: Carr, Sen Kim

talk.start.para: —The minister is quite correct. I thank her for drawing it to our attention. It is a typographical error. It should say division 1. Her officials ought to be congratulated for their eagle eyes on such matters. I therefore seek leave of the committee to amend our amendment so that it says division 1 and not division 2. Division 1 relates to grants for government schools and division 2 relates to grants for non-government schools.

speech.para: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —We have probably covered the ground quite thoroughly. The substantive questions with regard to the fact that the Commonwealth is shifting costs to the states highlight the grave dangers of this proposal. I can only presume that this is an unintended consequence. I suspect that my presumption is wrong and that this is the intent of this EBA in particular. Every state in Australia says that this will cost them in terms of its administration. Every state indicates that the Commonwealth's administrative assumptions are wrong.

speech.para:
The minister and the department have acknowledged in answers to questions in the estimates process and this chamber that they are planning to cut Commonwealth expenditure on government schools by $87 million over the next four years. In addition, the
government has cut financial assistance grants to the states by $1.5 billion over three years. How can the minister expect the states, in this context in which the government is providing less money, to spend more on schooling? Given the history of these matters, research that we have undertaken through the parliamentary research service and taking into account the rise in the schools cost index, the states have been spending considerably less in terms of outlays for schooling.

As a percentage of the total budget sector, their priorities for education have declined. Education's percentage of total budget outlays in the state of Victoria has declined from 26.8 per cent in 1989‐90 to 18 per cent in 1993‐94. This is a pattern which occurs across Labor and Liberal governments: that states are actually spending less on education. This government is cutting money to the states. How do they honestly expect to suggest in any logical way that suddenly they are going to spend more money? They will have less money, yet the government are suggesting that they are going to spend more.

speech.ministerial: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs
speech.speaker: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

talker.name: Senator VANSTONE
talker.role: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

talk.start.para: —With respect, Senator Carr, these matters have been canvassed with you on a number of occasions in this debate. I do not think it is going to be productive for us to go over the same ground. I simply repeat to you, as you are repeating your arguments to me, the proposition that the government has put: on the best available information to us at the moment, the states are increasing their spending on education. I will take you, Senator Carr, to the amendments—as Senator Allison seems unwilling or incapable of addressing the amendments that we have—because you, as soon as you were alerted to a possible problem, had the good sense to address it.

speech.para:
Can I take you to the amendments that we are, in fact, discussing rather than to the general second reading motion that some people would like to go on with for ever and a day? Can you indicate what the government asserts is the consequence of your amendment No. 1? We assert that you are obviously wanting to restrict the government from
taking money back vis‐a‐vis government schools. Do you accept that the consequence of your amendment is to prevent the government from properly taking money back, whether in the case of fraud, maladministration or overpayment, or that, by any accident that comes under that general umbrella, the Commonwealth would be unable to take the money back? You have drafted a blanket amendment to achieve one end but would be applying other limits.

talk.start.para: —Minister, you would be aware that the amendment refers to section 44, which sets down a whole range of criteria for accountability mechanisms. Division 1 establishes a whole range of criteria on the conditions for the application of financial assistance grants. This amendment seeks to highlight the fact that these things must be calculated in accordance with those criteria. Therefore the proposition you are putting forward is wrong. You have misunderstood the amendment.

speech.speaker: Allison, Sen Lyn

talk.start.para: —I think what we have been speaking about this morning is completely relevant. We are talking about removing the EBA. So discussion about whether or not the $2.3 billion is extra or it is some other figure is relevant because it is crucial to the government's argument. The government says the EBA is insignificant; that it is only one per cent or three per cent and so, because there is so much other funding going into education, we need not worry about it. I want to come back to that $96 million to state schools. I also did a calculation which showed that it was an increase of 1.7 per cent over four years. That is something like 0.4 per cent each year in that period. I would like to suggest that 0.4 per cent is not an increase because I would imagine it does not even begin to cover inflation over that period. On the other hand, $530 million to private schools is 6.27 per cent.

speech.para:
The minister said on 7 November that `funding per government school pupil will rise, taking these assumptions into account, to 17.9 per cent compared with non‐government per‐capita increases of 14.9 per cent'. So here we have another set of differences in terms of
the figures that the department produces and the figures plucked from the air by the government during this debate. I mention that again: $96 million to state schools is an increase of 1.7 per cent over four years, hardly enough to keep up with inflation. Five hundred and thirty million dollars goes to private schools—that is 6.27 per cent. However you, Minister, said that funding to government school pupils would rise, taking these assumptions into account, to 17.9 per cent, compared with non‐government, per‐capita increases of 14.9 per cent.

Now, you have actually made some calculations on the basis of the FAGs to the states and you have said that, all right, we are going to increase government school expenditure only by 1.7 per cent but we will assume that the states will increase their funding by 20.18 per cent.

For some reason, given that these are untied grants, given that $1.5 billion has been taken away from the FAGs over this period, you have assumed that the states will increase their spending on schools by 20.18 per cent. I directed a question on notice, question No. 39, to the department during the hearings about the guarantees in terms of states agreeing to fund education. The answer was that the decision at the 1996 Premiers Conference was that the states and territories would contribute to deficit reduction. DEETYA has no indication that states and territories have reduced their financial effort in schools as a consequence of this decision at the Premiers Conference.

You might argue, `Well, they didn't say they wouldn't. Therefore, that means they did, and they did to the tune of 20 per cent.' I think this stretches our credibility a long way. Even if you take into account those percentage increases, it still does not add up to the figures that you have produced. You have said that essentially government school pupils will have increases to their per capita funding at a greater rate than the private sector.

para.break: That simply does not wash, and I return to the table on page 14. The percentage increase of the FAGs to both government and non-government schools is the same—20.18 per cent. But the percentage increase to govern ment schools is very different. It is 1.7 per cent to government schools and 6.27 per cent to non-government schools. It is another indication that the government is using figures to promote its policy, but it is misleading. I think it has caused a great deal of confusion.

speech.para: You also said on 27 November that additional Commonwealth funding of $2.3 billion, which will be available for government schools, comes from two sources: firstly, the specific purpose payments to government schools and, secondly, the Commonwealth sourced financial assistance grants. I assume that you still stand by that comment, but I refer you once again to this table prepared by DEETYA which quite clearly shows otherwise. Either the government is trying to confuse people with the figures or there is simply not the understanding of the effects of that EBA.

It seems to me that you do not know whether there is an increase in funds or not and, if you do, then people are being misled. I invite you to respond to that. Perhaps you will need to do some calculations. The problem with the tables that we have been presented with is that there are no additions across the line. We are simply presented with year by year figures. What has consistently happened is that those calculations are not being done. We cannot see comparisons from one year to the next. We do not see comparisons with the year 2000 and the year 1996. We do not see the adding up, except where it suits the government's purposes. So I ask you to address that. Also with regard to that table—

talk.start.para: —Which table?

—It is the final column on page 14 of the report of the committee. This is a consistent table that has been used by me and the department. You will see that for government schools the increase is 16.66 per cent. I have just pointed out that that is made up of 20.18 per cent in FAGs and only 1.7 per cent in the real grants from the Commonwealth and, for non-government schools, 26.73 per cent. I seek a reconciliation of your statement on 7 November and those figures that are before us.
—What government was in power in Victoria when you left school?

—I am interested in this question. Clearly it was not a Democrat government, so I am not sure what you are asking me to defend. It was the Hawke government federally and, as I recall, it was the Cain state government. I do not defend Labor's position on schools. The Democrats have criticised the Labor Party for many years, because over the last 20 years we have seen a reduction in real terms of something like 20 per cent on education funding.
—The truth will out.
—I am happy to argue for an increase. If you would like to make good the damage done by—
—Order! Senator Allison, I think it would be more appropriate if the minister answered the question relevant to the issue that is before us.

speech.ministerial: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs
speech.speaker: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

talker.name: Senator VANSTONE
talker.role: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

talk.start.para: —I would like to make a couple of points. I do not know whether you have ever taught mathematics, but you do have a capacity to toss 53 different tables up in the air at the one time, come to your own conclusion and ask everybody to see clearly whatever it is that you have concocted together in your own mind.

speech.para:
I draw your attention to page 9 of the departmental submission, which I think is a pretty similar table to the one you are referring to. It shows how the calculations have been made. You are pretty loose sometimes with your comments. I noticed a little earlier that you said you were pleased I had corrected an assessment of the impact of the EBA from one to three. That is not the case. Each time I have referred to that, I have indicated that we calculate that to be about three per cent of SPPs or one per cent of FAGs and SPPs together. That has been perfectly clear, but you choose to flippantly say, probably because we are on broadcast, `You have changed your story on that.' Where the story does change, it needs to be acknowledged, but, where it has not, it is not appropriate for you to flippantly suggest that it has. I invite you to check the
Hansard
with respect to that matter.

break.para: I understand that in your earlier remarks you indicated that somehow the government was offering different figures from those which the department offered. I think your terminology was something like `You have plucked things out of the air'. You were referring quite specifically to the proposition put by me—and, if not, by Dr Kemp—that the percentage per capita change for government schools was about 17 and it was about 14 for non-government schools.

That in fact was in the departmental submission. There is no difference between the government and the department on these figures, and certainly not one that has become clear to me as a consequence of anything you have said. On that basis, I draw you to page 9 of the departmental submission to the committee's hearing and ask you yet again to accept that, for this place to work efficiently, we have second reading debates. That is the opportunity for people to put their views on general propositions about what ought to be the case. Then, when we have moved from that and we have passed our opportunities, we shift to the committee stage, which is the stage at which we, generally speaking, like to address the amendments to be made to the bill.

On two occasions I have tried—three or four, actually, in general, but two specifically—to bring us back to this. Senator Carr has had the decency to recognise that that is the purpose of a committee hearing. I ask you to contemplate the merit or otherwise of continuing with a rehash of the second reading debate where nothing further has been added.

talk.start.para: —Minister, I trust that you understood the comment I made regarding the concerns the department has raised about the amendments. We do not seek in any way under this amendment to detract from the administration of the grants for government schools other than, effectively, the removal of the EBA. Provisions relating to conditions for financial assistance, general conditions of financial assistance, specific conditions regarding financial accountability and education accountability are all met.

break.para: The criteria by which we seek to allocate money are changed, as via your proposal, and, as I say, the formula is set out in section 44 of the bill. We will be seeking subsequent amendments to ensure that the words `equal to' be used rather than the words `not greater than'. We are seeking to replace division 3, 19, `Powers of Minister if amounts of grants become repayable', to ensure that the provisions for the recouping of money for fraud or for any other breaches of the law will be maintained. I trust that our intentions have been explained clearly.

I understand that time is getting on and we will be seeking to take this matter to a division very shortly, but I put this view to you, Minister: during the term of the previous government, direct school funding rose by some 58 per cent in real terms. Yet, largely due to the actions of state governments, Australia's ranking amongst OECD countries in terms of spending on school education remained very low.

During the election your party told us that it was concerned about this. Minister, do you expect that the measures that you have outlined in this proposal—which involve the reduction in Commonwealth expenditure for government schools in terms of direct payments by some $87 million over the next four years and the reduction, one can conclude, in terms of the implications of the reductions in Commonwealth government grants to the states of $1.5 billion over the three years—which take further money from the states, are likely to encourage them to spend more money on schools?

This legislation has given you the opportunity to demonstrate national leadership—the vehicle by which governments in recent times have been able to provide the platform for the expression of their concerns about the direction for education in this country. The issue of national leadership is in itself of national significance in terms of education. Minister, why have you made your budget bottom line more important than the future of young Australians? Why have you broken your promise on this very vital issue? Instead of discussing with the states this whole question of expenditure by all governments of school
education in a mature way, you have imposed these cuts arbitrarily, without warning and without any regard to the problems you yourself identified before the election.

You told the Australian people as a party that, in government, you would be concerned about the way in which the states have reduced funding. You told the Australian people that you would do something about it. What you have done is in fact reduce funding for education, particularly for public education, by $87 million over the next four years in terms of the moneys you directly control. You have reduced financial assistance grants to the states by $1.5 billion over three years and changed the calculation of the way in which road funding and other measures have been added to the FAGs. Your claims that there is an increase in money, therefore, are bogus. Minister, I repeat: why have you made your budget bottom line more important than the future of young Australians?

speech.ministerial: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs
speech.speaker: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

talker.name: Senator VANSTONE
talker.role: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

talk.start.para: —Senator, I do not accept the proposition that you put. You consistently want to focus purely on the SPPs; you refuse to focus on the specific purpose payments and the FAGs. You either do not accept or ignore the best information we have available—that is, that the states will be increasing the amount of money that they are spending on education.

speech.para: We heard the reluctant announcement by Senator Allison about the time she reluctantly chose, apparently, to go to teach in the Catholic school system—there was a Labor state and federal government, according to her, so diminishing funding on government schools that she had no choice but to go to the Catholic system. I see her nodding. I am not sure that you are in any position, on the basis of Senator Allison's experience, to be lecturing this government on what it wants to do.

In very difficult times, Senator Carr, with billions and billions of dollars on the bankcard for this nation, there has been difficulty in generating new real jobs, and that is an area in which your government found difficulty because of its fiscal irresponsibility. The loss of confidence that creates in the
business community and the impact that the general fiscal incompetence of a government has on interest rates has impacted on the generation of real new jobs. You understand that and I might even suspect that some on your side have a grudging respect for this new government.

talk.start.para: —Ha, ha! `Respect' is not exactly the word that comes to mind.

—I would laugh, if I were you and that proposition were put to me, too, and I were on that side. The simple fact of the matter is: your government, during the election, refused to open the books to the Australian people. We were perfectly willing to have the books opened and policies on both sides assessed and reassessed on the basis of the books. Your government simply refused to open the books—an absolutely flat refusal. On coming to government, we found this enormous fiscal irresponsibility. There is nothing to be gained and there are no friends to be won in putting a budget back into black. There is no pleasure in saying to people, `You're going to get less money. We're going to have to tighten this up. We can't continue with this program.' Cleaning up a mess that a previous government made is not a politician's dream. Oh, no! It is not the land of milk and honey, coming into government and having to fix up a mess that the previous government created.

speech.para:
That is the situation that this government is in. Let us make no bones about it. The previous government made an unholy mess of running this country. That is why, after a very significant time in office, you lost government so comprehensively. The new government is prepared to fix that mess, to make those hard decisions. We are not going to walk away from the tough decisions that became too hard for an ageing government to make. Too many people in the previous government had never experienced opposition. They just waltzed into a party that was in government and had the mentality of spend, spend, spend other people's money, taxpayers' money, low‐income‐earning taxpayers' money, without regard for the consequences. The consequences of that are fairly clear, with such
lagging employment growth as was generated in the last few years of your government.

You referred to the bottom line of a budget disparagingly, as if, somehow, it is dirty work to put a government's budget back into black. I do not regard that as dirty work, Senator. I regard it as a job that has to be done, because previous governments were simply unprepared to do it. I can see the benefits of a nation that does have some fiscal responsibility. When everyone else has to keep their budgets in order, I do not see why a cabinet here should simply play with other people's money as though they are in a sandpit, without any regard for the responsibility that they bear, being the government, and the consequences of simply spend, spend, spend.

You may have the view, Senator, that when you are in government it is other people's money and you can do what you like with it, but we do not. We regard putting the budget back into black as not an easy task and not a pleasant task. It is never fun to go to people and say, `We're going to have to tighten up,' but that is the task we were elected to do. Weakly walking away from that task, as Old Jellyback and others did, means you walk away from the most disadvantaged people in the community. It means you walk away from the people who do not have a job, who are not sitting in here taking up extensive amounts of time and money rehashing debates over and over again, self‐indulgently. It means walking away from the lowest skilled people who are most at risk when you are in a recession. That is what it means. They are the sorts of people you walk away from: the small business people with large overdrafts and people with extensive mortgages trying to buy their own homes. You just leave the fiscal mess, let the interest rates rise, and walk away from those people.

I can imagine no government policy which can put as much money back into people's pockets as a reduction in interest rates does. How does that come about?
