Amendment No. 2 goes to the issue of the government's rationale for funding of non-government schools—that is, it seeks to explain that government schools are somehow or other an alternative. This is a view that the Labor Party does not support. We believe that, on the issue of choice, private schooling is an addition, not an alternative, in terms of providing reasonable access to quality government schooling.

It has been a fundamental principle of public schooling in this country that public schooling is primarily the responsibility of the public sector through governments. Since the education acts of last century, the various public instruction acts, all governments have acknowledged their responsibilities to provide comprehensive education available on a universal basis. Of course, many have said that it should be free, secular and universal. There may well be some argument as to what is the meaning of `free' in its modern context, but that principle has been firmly grounded in public administration in the Commonwealth throughout this century.

We are seeking to put in perspective the rhetoric about choice and we would like to emphasise to the chamber the role of the Commonwealth in underpinning a national quality public education system—and providing financial assistance also to the non-government sector, but not at the expense of the public sector. It is our belief that choice
exists only if there is a quality, universally accessible government school system. What we maintain is that the choice of some should not be at the expense of the choice of many.

What we argue and what Professor McKinnon highlighted is that there is a limit to the resources available. There are finite limits on resources available and we cannot logically argue that choice can be so broad as to fund every possible option of every group no matter how small or how isolated in terms of a private education system. In terms of our social responsibility, we have to primarily consider responsibilities to provide a high quality, universally accessible public education system.

Professor McKinnon argued, I think very competently, in the review he undertook, which was finally published in April 1996—a review, of course, which the government has sought to shelve, tried to bury in the bottom drawer, sought to avoid public discussion on:

Choice is easier to use as a rhetorical term than it is to operationalise, at least for the funding of schools. Generalised support for the concept of everyone having maximum choice does not translate into a system which can realistically fund all conceivable options. Nor is choice an unambiguous good.

The minority report, in considering these issues, argued that there is a significant weakness in the policy upon which the states grants bill is predicated, because it is meant to provide for the financial assistance to primary and secondary schools, but it does so with the notions of parental choice as its overarching purpose rather than as a general purpose directed towards educational outcomes.

para.break: It has been repeated by several witnesses before the committee that choice in itself has no impact on educational outcomes in terms of Australian schools. It is likely, however, that the deliberate favouring of private provision over public provision in our schools could quickly lead to a deterioration in the quality and the universality of public education, and hence our amendments seek to reinstate the basic principle that the central point held in common by all Commonwealth governments of all political persuasions over the last two decades is that its primary re sponsibility is to support the provision of a comprehensive universal education system so that Australians, no matter where they live, have access to high quality educational services.

speech.para: That cannot be done through the privatisation of education, because it is founded upon a whole series of different principles. It is not comprehensive. It does not seek to be comprehensive. Individual schools are established on the basis of the values that they see reflected in a particular group. For the disabled it cannot possibly be contended that there is comprehensive provision in private education. Time and again it has been put to Senate estimates committees, particularly for the disabled, the disadvantaged and a whole range of others, that choice is not really an option, because the private sector does not provide it. We will speak more about that when we come to the issues relating to broadbanding.

The amendments seek to recognise Australia's international treaty signatory obligations. They seek to identify that the primary role of government is to ensure that the quality of services is maintained at a high level for all Australians and that Australians, particularly if they come from backgrounds where they cannot afford private education and the provision of private fees and tuition, are not singled out for reduced services or isolated by the withdrawal of public support.

speech.speaker: Allison, Sen Lyn

talk.start.para: —The Australian Democrats support these amendments. We think these amendments place at least some restrictions on where schools can open, what their minimum number of enrolments should be, how viable they should be and what curriculum requirements should be put in place. They also set up a process under which the minister is obliged to take advice from state based non-government school planning committees. Those committees, in the Democrats' view, are appropriately structured under the opposition amendments and they are consistent with the notion that all parties should be involved in planning Australian schooling.

speech.para:
That really is the key to these amendments: there should be planning and it should happen
with the involvement of all parties. It is important to draw on some of the submissions to the inquiry in support of that. One is from the National Catholic Education Commission. It sought to persuade the government to set up some general principles for planning schools. For instance, it says that, since the Commonwealth government has a shared responsibility for the funding of education, it has a right and a responsibility in regard to new schools.

It offered as a suggestion for a minimum in terms of the process of consultation that proponents of new schools gain access to demographic and planning data at the state and territory level; consultative meetings between two or more education providers or from time to time between all peak provider bodies; the exchange of relevant information between peak school education authorities to avoid the overprovision of facilities by any one of the three providers; knowledge of other broad plans to help individual school systems; and provider planning. So it is not just the public sector which is arguing that sensible planning processes ought to be in place.

I think it would be appropriate at this stage to ask the government what it is going to do to ensure that there will be some sort of uniformity across the states when it comes to minimum registration requirements. Does the government accept that it is in the national interest to have uniformity in an area of such national significance as education? We heard at the inquiry the range of different registration requirements the states have. Many states said they thought they would need to develop their own planning requirements.

What I would like to ask the minister is along those lines. Are you asking the Senate to pass this bill with absolutely no idea of what agreements the states will develop themselves and whether or not the Commonwealth government will be part of that process? What sort of standards and requirements might there be at the end of such a process? I know that the government has said over and over again that it thinks that education is a state responsibility. But, as the Catholic Education Commission points out, it is Commonwealth funding. I would have
thought that it was at least an obligation of the Commonwealth government to see that we have at least some level of uniformity across Australia in this respect.

I would like to put that to the minister. Can we have some indication of what the federal government regards as being important in terms of those registration requirements and the need for uniformity? Is that or is that not important?

speech.ministerial: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs
speech.speaker: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

talker.name: Senator VANSTONE
talker.role: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

talk.start.para: —Of course all these things are important, Senator. As you know, these are things that are dealt with by the states. If you want to see a change in that, there are other measures you will have to take through this forum to get that sort of change.

—If the states develop their own de facto new schools policy—some are suggesting they may have to do this in order to prevent the chaos that the abandonment of the new schools policy would create and also the abandonment of the planning provisions the Commonwealth had for its own funding—and got together and it ended up being in line with the existing new schools policy, would the Commonwealth have an objection to that? Would that be a problem in terms of this bill?

speech.ministerial: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs
speech.speaker: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

talker.name: Senator VANSTONE
talker.role: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

talk.start.para: —One of the delights of a federal system is that if the Commonwealth does something, it is responsible and it has to answer to the electorate for it on each occasion. Similarly, when a state government chooses to implement a policy, it is answerable for that policy to the people of that state. We do not think it is appropriate that the Commonwealth maintain the Commonwealth new schools policy.

speech.para:
We think it is just plain wrong that there can be a policy which seeks to discourage parental choice in schooling. It is acknowledged in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights that Senator Carr was referring to and has referred to before by highlighting that everyone has a right to education. He has not gone on and pointed out that point 3 of article 26 says that parents have a prior right to
choose the kind of education that shall be given to their children.

We believe that the previous government's new schools policy—that is, the existing new schools policy—inhibits that choice very substantially. We think it is wrong that there are schools that do not have Commonwealth funding. Parents have been desperate to have an alternative choice and the Commonwealth is not funding them. We think that is wrong. We think parents should have the choice. They are entitled to some Commonwealth funding when they make that choice to move away. You might not think that. You might think they are only entitled to such choices as you are prepared to give them. We would like to give them greater choice than the new schools policy allowed.

Despite the fact that the new schools policy was set up to try to inhibit the growth of new non-government schools, they, nonetheless, grew. That is in the face of a very difficult policy climate. Non-government schools, nonetheless, kept springing up. That should tell you something, Senator. It should tell you that parents want to make that choice. That is why we believe it is appropriate to get rid of the new schools policy at a Commonwealth level because at a Commonwealth level we say that we are not interested in doing that. We do not want to inhibit parental choice. If a state wants to take it up and they want to argue the case with the parents in their state and they want to inhibit the parents' choice, let them do so. Let them answer for it at the next state election.

talk.start.para:
—In relation to this series of amendments, I think it is fair to say that there are some similarities in the states' regulation of new schools that might open and there are some differences. The minister is suggesting that that matter should be a matter entirely for the states. Given that statement, I ask the minister: does she have any concerns about the disparity which might arise, given different philosophies and governments with different policies on the establishment of schools and, therefore, potentially a different set of regulatory criteria in every state and territory of Australia? Is that going to be any problem
for the government with its philosophy? Does the minister think that that will be an area of aggravation and conflict within and between states with regard to the operation of the bill as proposed by the government?

speech.ministerial: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs
speech.speaker: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

talker.name: Senator VANSTONE
talker.role: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

talk.start.para: —There are differences now as a consequence of the states, so it is not as though I am suggesting that this amendment should not be accepted because we want to encourage or create differences. They are already there. This is the system that we had under your party's previous government for some 13 years. There are differences between the states now. If you do not want those differences, presumably, you want to say that all education should be controlled by the Commonwealth. That is a function of having a federal system. We have the differences now.

—What would the government do if it believed at some stage that state registration requirements were too low and if it came to the conclusion that the education of children in non-government schools in Tasmania or Queensland, for example, is at risk because of some particular unacceptable state requirement? What if you believe that national schooling standards are being jeopardised in some way? What power will the government have after this legislation passes to do anything about that?

speech.ministerial: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs
speech.speaker: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

talker.name: Senator VANSTONE
talker.role: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

talk.start.para:
—Senator, as you may understand, there are accountability requirements which can be watched. Your next question might be: what would happen if a state abandoned all regulation and just decided that everyone could do what they liked? We can sit here with a crystal ball, and you can take things out to the extremes if you choose. The facts are that we have an existing system, which has been operating for a considerable time, where the states have had these responsibilities. There is not much point in crystal balling here. They already have this capacity; there already are differences. We
could crystal ball as long as you like, but I am not able to see down that track.

speech.para: This is the system that we have had for some time. This system has been working well despite all its faults—no system that I know of in any area is completely perfect. If you want to raise support for removing any educational capacity from the states and giving everything in primary and secondary education to the Commonwealth, run that as a Democrat policy.

talk.start.para: —We can understand and even accept that you want to assist in the expansion of the private school sector. What we cannot understand is why the government wants to completely wash its hands of any role in the planning of that expansion. It seems to us that a consequence of this legislation will be that the Commonwealth will have no influence over where new private schools start up, how many students they have or what they teach. Does the government agree that it has absolutely no control over what goes on in those schools, despite the fact that it is handing them more than $2,000 per student in taxpayers' money?

speech.ministerial: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs
speech.speaker: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

talker.name: Senator VANSTONE
talker.role: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

talk.start.para: —Senator, as you know, the states have this capacity. They control now where government and non‐government schools go. Are you putting the proposition that the non‐government school sector is going to behave in a completely irresponsible fashion and put schools where they are not needed? Are you asking the government to consider the proposition that the Catholic system, which you worked for, is so irresponsible that it will just stick schools anywhere and that it will be allowed to do that by the states? Are you saying that you lack confidence in both the states and the Catholic school system?

speech.para:
Do you think that they will get into cahoots together to put schools where they are not required? Is that your response to the clear demonstration by parents that they want to be able to make a choice and to be able to support a private school? Do you think that everyone—parents, the Catholic school system
and the state governments—are all getting together to somehow persecute the government system?

speech.speaker: Allison, Sen Lyn

talk.start.para: —A number of schools did not receive funding under the new schools policy. I do not have the figures right here in front of me, but it was a considerable number. They did not receive funding because they did not qualify in terms of minimum enrolments. They did not receive funding because of the effect that the opening of that school would have on neighbouring Catholic, other non‐government and state schools. They did not receive funding because they could not demonstrate that they were viable.

speech.para: It seems to me that they are reasonable expectations to have. What you are concluding is that all non‐government schools will not be irresponsible. By saying to me that I am saying non‐government schools will be irresponsible, you are suggesting that the assumption you and the federal government make is that they will be responsible. I think, on the whole, that that is not an unreasonable suggestion. However, I would have thought that, since it is taxpayers' money, the federal government ought to have the ability to know that the states are responsible. Under this legislation it will not be able to do that. So it is a question of accountability. I do not think you can say that the states are accountable. It is Commonwealth funding, and the Commonwealth ought to have a say in whether or not it is getting value for that money.

We are talking here about efficiency and cost effectiveness, yet we are handing over enormous sums of money to people and to organisations from which the government has absolutely no power to demand that accountability. I suggest to you that that is not responsible and not a reasonable way to deal with such crucial national issues as education. You say it is the states' matter, but thus far the Commonwealth government has taken a role in planning at the national level. Through its programs and through its other mechanisms it said that there is a responsibility at that level. I think it is disappointing to see that the Commonwealth government is prepared to step aside from that.

break.para: What is also disappointing is that this is not about outcomes. It is not about things like retention rates. We do not know how they will be affected by this legislation. I turn to another table prepared by the department for the inquiry. This table looks at retention rates and shows that there are huge differences between government and non-government schools. I dare say we could have a debate about why that is.

This legislation does not seek to address education outcomes. It seeks to open up the private sector without any controls. It does not assist in providing a better education for either the non-government or the government sector because there will be some non-government schools affected by this.

Certainly, the Catholic system will be one of those affected. The Catholic system has grown at a consistent and small rate over the years. It is a properly planned system. It does not open up schools with one, two or six students. It does its own planning and that has been healthy for education in this country.

What we are talking about here in an unplanned expansion—and that is what the government is doing—is very small schools starting up. I referred to this in a speech I made on Wednesday. The point is that the Commonwealth no longer has any control. We cannot say that we do not need a school here or that we do. We cannot say that, if a new school opens up in a small country town, the effect of it will be to take students from government schools and the effect of that will be for the state government to close down those schools because they are no longer viable.

I have already mentioned that in Victoria our state government has changed its requirements for its own schools. Now it will close another 113 schools because they do not have enough enrolments. It has changed its enrolment requirement—it has doubled it in some cases—and so schools will close down.

At the same time, the minimum enrolments the Victorian government has are very low for non-government schools. In every other state in Australia there are no minimums, so we can have schools starting up with one or two students and they will attract $2,000 per
student from the Commonwealth. You may say that is responsible. I would suggest that that is no way to plan a national education system.

speech.ministerial: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs
speech.speaker: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

talker.name: Senator VANSTONE
talker.role: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

talk.start.para: —I understand one aspect of what you are trying to say, I think; that is, you do not think it is appropriate that the states have this control, and what would we do if the states did other than what we thought? I ask you to indicate, because it could help me to understand your view: why do you think it is appropriate that there are 52 schools with state recognition that are unfunded by the Commonwealth? Why do you think it is appropriate that the states are prepared to recognise 52 schools and the Commonwealth refuses to fund them?

—One is a question of funding and one is a question of registration. The state governments have developed criteria for registration based on the knowledge that there is a new schools policy which takes care of things like viability and effect on other schools. The states have never had to develop criteria to judge whether or not it is appropriate for particular schools to set up in their area. They have not needed to do that, so they do not. That is why they each have a different set of criteria. They certainly do have it for their own schools. I suggest to you that it is likely that the states will develop their own de facto new schools policy. I think that would make a lot of sense. Once again, it is Commonwealth funding and I would have thought the Commonwealth should play a role in that.

speech.ministerial: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs
speech.speaker: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

talker.name: Senator VANSTONE
talker.role: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

talk.start.para: —You identify that states have not necessarily taken responsibility and that under this changed arrangement they would have it. I am still interested in why you think it is appropriate that the states should have recognised 52 schools and we should refuse to fund them. Why do you think it is appropriate that we should refuse to fund 52 schools that the states are prepared to approve?

speech.speaker: Carr, Sen Kim

talk.start.para: —Is it not the case that, nationally, there are no consistent registration procedures? You can have a different criteria established in each of the states. Is it not the case that the new schools policy under Labor in fact provided a framework for the operations of planned education provision?

speech.para: The reliance upon the states to provide that is flawed intellectually because they have demonstrated for many years that they do not have the political will to establish guidelines and criteria on very simple matters like teacher registration, for instance. That is a simple proposition. Not all states require the qualifications of teachers to be recognised. They have all sorts of ways around it. They do not have a national approach to questions of financial viability. Very few states—in fact, one from my recollection—have any criteria based on the concept of financial viability.

As to the concept of minimum enrolments, which you would expect to have some relationship to the issue of financial viability, the states as a rule do not have criteria. There is one state that does—Victoria. It has a substantially different criteria for private sector enrolments and private sector enrolments, by a factor of some 40 to one. There is a minimum requirement of 10 in a private primary school and 400 in a public school. That sort of inconsistency and hypocrisy is just breathtaking. For you to stand here and ask such a silly question is really quite extraordinary, Minister. I would have thought you would know a little bit more about it than that.

Is it not the case, Minister, that on the one hand you claim that the problem with the exercising of choice under the new schools policy was that, somehow or another, the new schools policy prohibited the growth of private sector? Yet we saw an expansion in the private school sector of some three per cent over the total enrolments throughout the operation of that policy. Most applications, in fact the overwhelming number, particularly in the Catholic education system, were in fact run and successful. On the other hand, you say, `We have to get rid of this restriction on the growth of private schools, but we do not
expect to see a massive mushrooming in the numbers of students entering private schools.'

Which is it? Was the new schools policy a device which restricted, unfairly and illegitimately, the growth of private schools? Or was it the case that the removal of the new schools policy will not lead to the mushrooming of private schools? Which one is the truth?

talk.start.para: —Senator O'Brien?
—Could I get an answer to that question? It was seeking a direct response.
—I thought the minister might like to respond to a number of issues that have been raised.

speech.ministerial: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs
speech.speaker: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

talker.name: Senator VANSTONE
talker.role: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

talk.start.para: —I would, but I will briefly respond to this to satisfy Senator Carr. Senator Carr, as you know, in South Australia and in the Northern Territory some quite substantial planning is undertaken by the states. It is a recommendation of MCEETYA that the others do. Maybe you disagree with that.
—They haven't, have they?
—People do not always take up recommendations as quickly as they should.

speech.para:
Senator Carr interjecting
—

talk.start.para: —Senator, if you know the answers, there is not much point in my giving you my view.

speech.speaker: O'Brien, Sen Kerry

talk.start.para:
—In relation to the issue of the performance of the states, I think there are two issues that we need to look at. If we look at the requirements of the states for registration, your state of South Australia, Minister, has no official requirement. It relies upon the new schools policy. It may review that; it may not. New South Wales has no requirement. Queensland is in the same position as your state. Western Australia has no requirement. Tasmania has a requirement for a minimum of two for families, and I guess that means a minimum of two students. The ACT has no
requirement, and the Northern Territory has a slightly more complex provision.

speech.para: If we look at the list of unfunded or part-funded schools that your department, in answer to a question 19 in estimates, communicated to us, in your state of South Australia there are no schools that are totally unfunded. There are two schools that are category six limitation funded. So, in effect, the new schools policy has restricted funding but not stopped funding of any school. There are no schools operating—according to the answer that DEETYA gave us to question No. 19—that are totally unfunded.

If you look at that same document, it appears to me that the overwhelming majority of schools that are unfunded are in the states of New South Wales, Western Australia and Queensland. I think they are the states—according to the information that I have as to the requirements for registration—that have no minimum number requirement. So we have a correlation that, where there is no minimum requirement for the number of pupils, there is a higher number of unfunded schools. This bill removes any restriction on funding. So those schools will be funded because there is no requirement.

I think the persistent stance of this government is, `We don't have money. We can't splash money around everywhere.' There are limitations. We have this alleged black hole. At the same time, there is going to be no financial stringency applied in relation to these schools, whereas there is now.

In relation to the schools that are established in the non-government sector, I think the evidence is that, prior to the new schools policy where there was no limitation on funding, a number of schools opened were not viable and closed. I think the evidence in relation to that was the evidence from the Independent Education Union, Minister, which talked about a concern for the destabilising effect that these non-viable schools had on some of the smaller communities. They mentioned communities in rural and regional New South Wales, in particular.

It seems to me that these provisions in the bill will see us re‐embark upon the course that existed prior to 1985. It has not. So I think it
would be interesting to get the minister's view as to whether the situation which existed prior to 1985 is the situation that this bill seeks to obtain. If the experience prior to 1985 was not satisfactory to the Commonwealth or to at least some participants in the sector, why should we be rushing to pass a measure now, given that there is clearly no common view amongst the states about the need to pursue this measure at this time?

It would seem that, if there is a desire for some sort of consultative federalism on such an important issue, it would be more appropriate to obtain through meetings of state and federal ministers some consistency and some agreement. This is far from unheard of. There are many policy areas in which this has occurred. It would seem that there would be a more rational and reasonable approach to this issue to pursue agreement on these matters.

I understand, Minister, that you are saying, `Well, it's all a matter for the states,' but there are very great financial implications for the states. I would describe this particular measure as a risk strategy—one could be more unkind and say that it is a strategy to visit any odium on the states and not on the Commonwealth—in that the government is taking a risk that the outcome will be satisfactory to the Australian people.

I would think this government would not want it said in the future that it was cavalier with regard to the interests of the Australian community with regard to education. Perhaps, having said that, the minister has considered some of the earlier issues as well as being briefed on those issues as I made them. The minister might like to make some comments on those issues and on some of the previous comments that have been made.

speech.ministerial: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs
speech.speaker: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

talker.name: Senator VANSTONE
talker.role: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

talk.start.para:
—I will try to be as quick as I can. I realise that everybody has an entitlement to speak, but I am conscious of the fact that we have spent about four hours in the committee stage and only dealt with one batch. Nonetheless, let us look at the consequences of the new schools policy. Senator O'Brien is looking into a
crystal ball at what he hopes are not the consequences of these measures. He is looking at the most negative consequences he could possibly imagine as a result of changing the policy.

speech.para: I ask him to focus on the consequences of keeping it as it is. Look at Tasmania. The Circular Head Christian School at Smithton is a school with unfunded secondary students.

talk.start.para: —How many? What is the size of the school?
—There are 59 at that school.
—There are 59 in the whole school.

—I would like to say that there are 59 parents. There might be less than that. The children may have some brothers and sisters at the school. But the parents of the kids at the Circular Head Christian School obviously believe that that is an appropriate education for their children. I draw your attention to article 26 of the declaration of rights, which states that parents have a prior right to choose the kind of education that should be given to their children.

speech.para: The Devonport Christian School has unfunded primary school students. The Geneva Baptist School at Latrobe has unfunded primary and secondary students. The Kingston Christian Community School has unfunded secondary school students.

talk.start.para: —How big are these schools? How many students?

—I will give more information, if you like. I will go through them for you from here on rather than perhaps go back. The Launceston Rudolf Steiner School has 11 primary school students. You may think that is inappropriate, but they are unfunded. The Somerset Baptist Christian School also has unfunded students. The Kingston Christian Community School has unfunded secondary students. The Geneva Baptist School that I referred to has some unfunded secondary students. Senator O'Brien quite rightly points out that in my state the effect of the new schools policy is simply to limit two schools to category 6. You may say,
`So what.' I imagine that they would like to shift out of that position.

speech.para: I will not go through all of them because I am conscious of the time. I do not want to take up the time of senators unduly. Let us shift to the state of Queensland. The Ananda Marga primary school has 24 unfunded students. The Bundaberg Christian College has a category 6 limitation. It would otherwise be category 7. Senator O'Brien may say that that is not a problem, but if you are category 6 and you want to be category 7, I imagine that it would be of some interest to you.

The Cape Flattery Silica Mines School has seven students. Cape Flattery via Cooktown is a fair way away. I do not see why, if in that very isolated area people want to have a particular school, it should be unfunded because of this policy. The Christian Outreach College at Gympie has funded primary students but unfunded secondary students. You might say that the Cooloola Christian College is another one that has money and is a category 6 school. However, its proposed category is category 9. The Faith Christian College at Pialba has unfunded primary and secondary school students. The Glenden Christian School at Glenden is an unfunded school. The Goondiwindi Christian Education Centre is an unfunded school.

The Harmony Montessori school at Buderim is an unfunded school. The Hinchinbrook Christian School is an unfunded school. The Islamic School of Brisbane has a category 6 limitation. We propose that it should be a category 8 school. The Maleny District Community Learning Centre is an unfunded school. The Noosa Pengari Steiner School is an unfunded school. The Norman Park Christian school is an unfunded school. The Peace Christian Community School at Rockhampton has a category 6 limitation. We believe that it should be in category 8.

You do not seem to care about all these things. You seem to think the parents who have made the choice to send their kids to the Peace Christian Community School at Rockhampton, for example, because of the previous government's schools policy, deserve to be limited to category 6 funding and should
not be shifted to category 8. You do not think anything of that. You think it is just tough luck for them.

St Stephens College in Coomera is limited to category 6. The School of Total Education has some unfunded students, although I admit that it does not have many unfunded students. The Sinai College has a category 6 limitation. We think it should be category 7. The Tambourine Mountain College is an unfunded school. The Glennie School at Toowoomba has unfunded students. It does not have many but, nonetheless, it does have some, and they are primary school students. The Toowoomba Christian College has unfunded students and a category 6 limitation. We think it should otherwise be in category 8.

I will come back to the schools Senator O'Brien mentioned that are in my state. He seemed to say that the Heritage College at Oakden and the Horizon Christian School have money. They are limited to category 6, but are proposed to be category 11 or 12. It is not as though this category 6 limitation is something that you can easily ignore. I referred to the Yealering Aboriginal community school this morning in response to Senator Carr's inquiry about the impact of shifting to per capita funding. I was pleased to sign an agreement with them under the IESIP funding. It has some unfunded students in relation to these matters, as does the Yallingup Steiner School at Yallingup and St Andrews Grammar School at Dianella.

Parents are entitled to make these choices. We believe it is fair enough that these schools are entitled to some funding. We think this new schools policy has operated to say, `You can have the choice, but we will not help you with it.' That is really not much choice at all. We think you should have the choice, and we will help in any event.

speech.speaker: O'Brien, Sen Kerry

talk.start.para:
—I cannot speak with any specific knowledge of the Queensland situation but I did make the point earlier that there is no restriction on establishment by number of pupils in Queensland. That is the situation as I understand it. So it is hardly surprising that schools unrestrained by state regulation have sprung up. To the extent that there are many that are part‐funded
that is probably an issue about whether you want to make changes to the new schools policy, particularly given their recommendations to change the new schools policy.

speech.para: Let me turn to the issues you raise about the Tasmanian schools, Minister: you may not be aware but there have been significant reductions in the number of government schools in Tasmania on the grounds of financial restriction and the efficiency of the system on the basis announced by the government that some of the smaller schools were unable to supply a satisfactory educational experience because of their limited size. Points have been made by the representatives of various parts of the non‐government schools sector that they want to have curriculum standards set by the state and they want to be viable.

I suggest to you that two matters are under consideration here. The first matter is that there are schools which are currently established that are not fully funded, and there is the issue of whether any of those should be looked at again; and I suggest that looking at the new schools policy again was already being contemplated. There is a report. I think that our amendments have regard to some of those issues. So some of those schools that you have mentioned would, in fact, under our proposal receive additional funding.

In relation to the issue of establishing more schools, because that is what your policy will permit under the arrangements that now exist within the states, we will see in my state an erosion of the dollars which go to the government school sector. That is the sector that educates the vast majority of the pupils in Tasmania. So in an unrestrained environment, and given the current political climate in Tasmania—I think there is a degree of inertia with the Tasmanian government at the moment—we could not be confident that this matter would be addressed expeditiously. I am concerned that we may see an erosion, by the government not doing what it should, of the funding basis of the state schools by simply transferring money across to the non‐government schools.

We have experienced a number of school closures in Tasmania; it was a very painful
experience for the community. I make this prediction, Minister: if things occur in such a way as to cause further restriction of the funding of the government school sector, there will be a significant backlash. The philosophy behind this bill—allowing parents to send children to schools that they want—will have to be attended to and undermined by a state government in the interests of maintaining their sector. You say that is a political problem for them.

I thought the resolution of the state aid debate was about taking it out of the political area and getting a formula, an arrangement, by which all sectors could live. I take it from what your government is saying that you have no concern about that. So I think it is important to put on the record that, having no concern, you do not believe that will happen, and you may be right; frankly, I hope that you are because I think it will be a very painful experience in the community of Tasmania, and a lot of people will regret the passage of this legislation. That is why I think our amendments do attend to some of the problems that you mention but do not allow an open slather approach to the establishment of new schools. They are amendments which are worthy of very strong consideration.

speech.speaker: Carr, Sen Kim

talk.start.para: —Minister, you made some claims about the operations of the new schools policy. I refute those claims, particularly those claims relating to the question of financial viability and curriculum choice. The prospect of a high school operating with 20 students, or 50 students for that matter, providing the range of educational experiences that one can expect from modern teaching—any school having the financial resources with 50 students to offer that full range in terms of specialist teaching—seems to me to be patently obviously impossible to provide.

speech.para:
The notion that a small primary school with 10 students in it is an ideal that we should be striving for strikes me as inappropriate. We all know from our history the difficulties of one‐teacher schools in remote and isolated communities. This policy institutionalises those failings which, of course, were failings as a result of our geography and demography.
They are not something to be applauded. The courage of teachers undertaking those duties in bygone days has to be acknowledged but it is not something we should be trying to aspire to in the 21st century because that is the pattern that is being established by this bill.

Since 1985 those seeking to establish new government schools have been required under the old policy, of course, to demonstrate the school satisfied a range of planning criteria and on that basis funds were made available by the Commonwealth. That policy provided the framework for planned educational provision across this country. And the states operated underneath that umbrella. You are proposing to take the umbrella away and then say to this chamber, `Well, we will rely on the states to plug up the gaps when the rain comes in.' That clearly just will not happen.

The political weakness of the position you are putting assumes that state governments will have the political will to undertake the necessary planning provision against some of these highly organised and very vocal religious groups in the main who will pursue a political agenda. I really question whether there will be the political courage at a state level to defend planned educational provision. State planning committees were in place under the old legislation, which you are seeking to overturn today. These included representatives from non‐government and government school authorities.

They provided advice to the Commonwealth on whether proposals for new schools satisfied the criteria relating to planned educational provision. You are losing that opportunity. This bill takes that opportunity away and reduces the capacity of the Commonwealth to effectively administer the expenditure of some $2 billion a year. Despite the requirements of the new schools policy, and contrary to your claims that there was an undue restriction on applications, the majority of applications for new schools were able to demonstrate consistency with the principles of planned educational provision.

During the operations of the new schools policy, discussions with other school authorities ensured that there was a much more
effective use of Commonwealth resources and a much more effective use of resources within the private sector. I think to suggest otherwise would be clearly wrong. Non-government enrolments grew by 126,000 in 1985 to over 900,000 nationally in 1995. The ratio of students in the non‐government sector increased from 26 per cent in 1985 to 29 per cent in 1995.

Since 1985, 95 per cent of applications from the Catholic education authorities satisfied the criteria. The Catholic education system in particular enjoyed considerable benefit from this new schools policy. That was especially the case in New South Wales. I am advised that the schematic Catholic schools, in particular, were able to quite effectively identify a predictable share of school population. They were able to manage very well to ensure that the Catholic education system in this country could meet the challenges of rationalisation and changes that occurred with the result of demographic and economic imperatives.

It was quite effective in ensuring that enrolments in the Catholic education system were able to meet the challenges of difficult times. Two‐thirds of all non-government enrolments have grown from Catholic schools, but the highest rate of growth that you are proposing is from other groups in our society. You are seeking to cater for a range of so-called Christian schools outside the Catholic education system. It is not just Christian schools but also a whole range of religious groups that you are seeking to cater to.

The average rate of enrolments in independent schools has been about three per cent per annum since 1985. The average increase across Australia has been about 9,000 nationally each year. As a result, the independent school sector has increased its share of total enrolments from 5.4 per cent in 1985 to 7.9 per cent. The new schools policy under the Labor government—and I make this very clear so it is at least on the public record—reflected a number of inter‐related concerns which I do not believe this government has sought to seriously address.

The new schools policy sought to plan new non‐government schools in a way consistent
with the need to cater for the growth and the shift in overall school populations. You have no provision for that. The new schools policy sought to avoid the tensions which became apparent from uncoordinated growth in non‐government schools places in areas already well provided. You have no provision within your legislation to cater for that. The new schools policy sought to cater for the needs relating to the various forms of educational disadvantage, and this bill does not cater for that. The broadbanding proposals in this bill do not effectively cater for that in the public sector, and they are fundamentally flawed in regard to the private sector.

The new schools policy sought to provide for orderly development of non-government schools without seriously reducing the standards of service in existing schools either government or non-government, and this bill has no response to that. The new schools policy sought to promote the economic use of public resources, and this bill provides for open slather. You have no response to that provision of promoting the economic use of very scarce public resources.

The amendments that the Labor Party have moved with regard to the schedule are 2 to 10, 12, 14 and 20. We are taking them together. We understand that, according to the nature of these things, we will vote on them together. What we are seeking to do is to focus attention on the planned educational provision which this bill currently abdicates. The non-government sector over the last 10 years has been funded by the Commonwealth in accordance with a range of criteria that I have just outlined. This bill does not have any response to those fundamental criticisms of the unrestrained, unplanned growth of the private sector.

Non-government schools, as outlined in the National Catholic Education Commission to the Senate committee inquiry, indicated that there was likely to be a continued growth as a result of the changes that were made under the new schools policy, and that was growth that was likely to continue. What the National Catholic Education Commission supported was proper planning provisions—planning provisions which Labor was seeking to put
back into this legislation—and a very basic and minimum requirement of the process of consultation with other educational authorities.

Proponents of the new schools gained access to demographic and planning data at a state and territory level. You have no provision in this bill for that to occur. Consultation meetings between educational authorities were important to ensure that all players within education had an opportunity to understand where the industry was going and to provide for effective coordination, as I say, of scarce government resources.

I do not think it is unreasonable that if we are handing out over $2 billion of Commonwealth funding a year there should be a nationally consistent approach to planned educational provision. It is irresponsible to dispense millions of taxpayers' dollars based on a registration system which, as we have already indicated in this debate, is fundamentally flawed, is not geared to planning provisions across this country and which has no recognition of the importance of the impact of decisions being made by one group of people in the education community on others within the education community.
McKinnon highlighted the exercise of freedom of choice in his report. He said that choice is not an unambiguous good. He goes on to say:

Increased choice for some may result in decreased choice for others. Choice in all schools may be limited in an area where enrolments are limited and, the more thinly spread, the more limited the curriculum. Similarly, in an area well served with schools but where there is a limited choice of the type of school, latecomers may effectively be prevented from offering wider choice.

The resolution of the very practical problem of how do you distribute very scarce educational resources is not adequately responded to by saying, `We'll just leave it to the market.' These are much more important issues than can be determined by a market distribution or mechanism. The future of our children demands more of this parliament than to say, `We'll just leave it to the market,' and that is essentially what this government is doing.

What we are seeking in our amendments is to require non-government schools to seek to
establish or significantly change their operation, to put their proposals before state based committees and to provide information to other players within the educational community. What we are seeking to do is to place back into this legislation the provisions of the new schools policy as well as to effect changes to that policy to reflect the legitimate criticisms that have been made.

We are not standing here flat-footed and saying that all that went on before should continue. We are saying there needs to be a constant process of review and updating. That is what the McKinnon report was all about. Our amendments seek to clarify those issues and seek to improve the provision of planned educational services across this country in a manner which will genuinely meet the needs of Australians into the future. This bill quite clearly fails in that regard.

What we are seeking to do, as I have indicated, is to ensure the protection of the choice of all Australians and to make sure that choices are not exercised by the few at the expense of the many. What this government has failed to do is to live up to its obligations and to understand its responsibilities in terms of the provision of those issues.
These principles that I have outlined in terms of the new schools policy, as far as I am concerned, were a fundamental ingredient in the settlement of the state aid debate.

talk.start.para: —Another second reading speech.

—That is very important. The Manager of Government Business in the Senate suggests that this is just another second reading speech, but it is important to explain, even to those who have closed minds on these issues, our attitudes in regard to these matters.

speech.para:
We have sought to move a series of amendments to highlight the deficiencies in this government's legislation. As I say, those principles that were outlined in the new schools policy were very much part of the settlement of the state aid debate in the mid‐1980s. As far as I am concerned, they were a series of compromises, and they were never perfect, like most compromises. But what you
are doing as far as I can see is to re‐open those issues. You are taking away the fundamental obligation that you have to the people of this country to ensure that there is reasonable provision and that there is reasonable expenditure of public dollars in such a manner that does not seriously disadvantage the financial and educational opportunities and of course the social and political opportunities of Australian citizens into the future. You have failed miserably in that regard, Minister.

speech.speaker: Allison, Sen Lyn

talk.start.para: —I do not want to unnecessarily prolong this debate. I would say, however, that I think Senator Carr has made some important points about the problems of the emergence of many more smaller schools and to say that that is quite contrary to the notions of efficiency that this government has espoused so far. I also want to speak in relation to the issue of choice.

speech.para: I speak on behalf of children in this respect. If we are to see more of our children in much smaller schools, we will see them having a less of a choice in terms of the range of subjects, less choice in terms of the sorts of facilities that they can use in schools and less choice socially as well. The more you concentrate our children into small schools, the more you remove those choices.

Before we wrap up this debate, I want to mention one aspect of planning which has not been dealt with so far in the debate, and that is the provision for children with disabilities. It is a planning issue. It is one that the government ought to have paid more attention to in this legislation. In fact, the government shows in schedule 8 that funds for special education have remained the same over the 1997-2000 quadrennium in government and non-government schools. It is interesting, given that we are going to see a shift into private schools, that there has not been a consequential shift of funding for disability services.

The National Catholic Education Commission pointed this out. They said that they were disappointed that the government did not make the provision that it had promised in the election context for additional support for disabled children. They also said that the
special education area is not adequately catered for in this bill and was not adequately catered for under the previous arrangements either.

I note that the government did promise an additional $6 million for disabled students before the election. This has not turned up, neither has there been recognition that there will be some disabled children who will also wish, presumably,—amongst the 23,000 who will exit state schools—to do likewise, that is, go into private schools. If the government is serious about choice, it ought to provide that choice for parents of disabled children too. In fact, the department was going to come back to me with some figures on the levels of students with disabilities in private schools, but I have not seen that so far.

This is an important question and one which the government ought to address. As I say, it is a planning matter and one which I would like to see the Commonwealth government continue, or at least resume, an interest in. I will finish now by supporting Senator Carr's and Senator O'Brien's remarks about schools and about the need to plan for them. It is a great disappointment to the Democrats that the government is stepping back from that responsibility.

speech.ministerial: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs
speech.speaker: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

talker.name: Senator VANSTONE
talker.role: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

talk.start.para:
—To respond to Senator O'Brien and others who seem to have the view that the states have no interest at all in the setting up of schools, I draw their attention to page 801 of the discussion paper on the review of the new schools policy. The table on that page highlights state and territory non‐government school registration requirements. Senator O'Brien, I think you are stretching a longbow to say that it is completely unregulated in Queensland. You focus on the fact that there is no minimum enrolment requirement there, but you do not bother to mention to everybody else who might be listening that there are requirements vis‐a‐vis curriculum, vis‐a‐vis school organisation, vis‐a‐vis the physical environment, vis‐a‐vis teacher qualifications, and with respect to financial viability. With the greatest of respect, to focus simply on the fact that there is
no minimum enrolment requirement and to extrapolate from that that it is a completely unregulated system, is perhaps not appropriate. For those senators who are interested in what the state registration requirements are, I refer them to page 801.

This amendment moved by the Australian Democrats is in recognition of the fact that neither the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone) nor the department has been able to provide this chamber with a clear picture of the impact of these changes. Even the government majority on the Senate Employment, Education and Training Legislation

I said in my speech during the second reading debate, and I will say it again: no‐one knows what the outcome of these changes will be. Nobody has the data on which to base any meaningful assessment of the impact of these changes on public schools. Not one single person in the entire country could stand up here and say that they know where this will end.

That is the risk the majority of this chamber have taken in passing this legislation. They have taken that risk, and the Democrats believe the very least this chamber should do is put in place an open and accountable monitoring process to enable a parliamentary review of the operation of the legislation every 12 months. Where else will people go if they have concerns about the impact of this bill? The short answer is: there is nowhere else to go. There are no planning committees, no review procedures and no other means of looking at what is happening as this legislation starts to bite.

This sort of monitoring role for a Senate committee is not new. This chamber has previously accepted this role when there has been concern about the implications of pieces of legislation. Perhaps the most notable in recent years was the reference to the Senate community affairs committee to monitor the operation of the previous government's private health insurance reforms because of concerns expressed by the medical profession at the time.

If we can take doctors' concerns seriously enough to set up a Senate monitoring process, surely we can take just as seriously the concerns of parents, teachers and state governments. speech.speaker: Schacht, Sen Chris

talk.start.para:
—The Shipping Grants Legislation Bill 1996 is a clear indication that this new government does not have an industry
policy of any consequence. The way this bill has been handled and the way the measures in this bill have been put forward clearly demonstrate this government's complete lack of industry policy.

speech.para: In the last two to three months, there has been an ever growing chorus from Australian business people, from manufacturers in particular, including the shipbuilding and shipping industries, about the need for a decent industry policy in this country. The call to have a vision about where manufacturing should go, and in particular where our shipping industry should go, has been made many times.

Though this bill does not deal with the issue of the ships bounty, it is in many ways related to the lack of philosophy this new government has towards our shipping industry in Australia. We have strenuously opposed the abolition of the ships bounty for our shipbuilding industry, a shipbuilding industry that now, in the fast ferry and fast ship area, is a world leader—employing thousands of people and each year selling to the world ships to the value of several hundred millions of dollars. It is an industry that is growing.

With this new government we are seeing that bounty come to an end. We will be one of the few countries in the OECD, if not the only one, that will provide no assistance to the shipbuilding industry. Yet we will be selling our ships into markets that are corrupted by the provision of tariffs, subsidies and non-tariff measures to encourage the development of shipbuilding industries.

When we were in government, we made it clear that we were not opposed to removing subsidies, bounties and non-tariff measures but only on the basis that every other country that was building ships did the same. We made it clear that, in particular, we would look towards the United States of America to repeal the so-called Jones act, which prohibits ships manufactured in Australia being sold into the American market. It prohibits our fast ferries, which are the world's best, most efficient and most technological advanced, being sold into that market.

para.break: We have strenuously opposed the government's decision to abolish the bounty legisla tion for this industry. Anybody who has any knowledge of this area is extremely proud of the industry which has been built, designed and created by Australians. But it is now being severely affected by this new government's decision.

speech.para: The Shipping Grants Legislation Bill is another example of a move away from any idea that we should have an involvement as a government in encouraging an indigenous shipping industry in Australia. The overall philosophy of the existing provisions goes right back to the 1980s. I have been advised that they were developed even by a previous coalition government. Mr Hunt, when he was the minister for transport, started the process that led to the introduction of the Ships (Capital Grants) Act in 1987. The purpose of that legislation was to encourage Australian owned shipping companies to purchase up-to-date ships to operate as registered Australian ships both in the domestic market and in the international market. But this government wants to repeal all of this. It is not encouraging an Australian owned shipping industry. I think in this we see the heavy hand in particular of the new Treasurer, Mr Costello.

There would be some advisers in the Treasury, I am sure, who would see legislation such as the Ships (Capital Grants) Act as an unnecessary interference in the free market. The people who say that have no conception of what is in the national interest in Australia. They believe that if you leave it to the free market other things will occur—sometimes by osmosis or by some sort of transcendental activity—so that somehow, out of nothing, an Australian shipping industry will develop.

We do not take that view in opposition. We never took that view in government. We believe this legislation is wrongly conceived and is against the national interest. We believe, in general, that these measures will seriously undermine the viability of the Australian industry. The loss of a viable, national industry can and should be opposed for a number of reasons, including the decimation of the industry, which will have a negative effect on the net services component of the current account.

break.para: The Bureau of Transport Economics estimated for 1986-87 that, if there had been no merchant fleet, the current account deficit would have been increased by $440 million—about 14 per cent of the services deficit and about four per cent of the current account deficit. Of course, we have had the Treasurer lecturing Australians over the recent months that the No. 1 issue he wants to deal with is the current account deficit. He wants to turn it around, but you have introduced legislation that will exacerbate the current account deficit in the services area.

The decimation of the national merchant fleet would affect our defence capacity. Several ship owners have entered into a memorandum of understanding with the navy to provide assistance in case of a national emergency. Some might even have facilities on their ships to specifically assist the navy. The lack of trained seafarers may also make emergency crewing of the navy more difficult in a national emergency.

Sea transport, of course, is environmentally more desirable than some modes of land transport. In terms of energy consumption, bulk shipping uses only 0.2 megajoules per tonne/kilometre as compared to 0.4 for government rail and 1.4 for articulated trucks. In terms of greenhouse gas emissions, bulk sea transport generates 13 grams of CO2 per tonne/kilometre, as compared to 29 grams for government rail and an even higher rate of grams for the trucking business.

This government in recent times has shown no interest in the greenhouse gas emissions issue. It even had the embarrassment of being properly lectured by the American President, when he was here last week, about the need for international rules for greenhouse gas emissions that are legislatively binding on countries. Our new government has steered right clear of that and, as a result, was severely embarrassed by the President's remarks in his successful visit to Australia last week.

Australian crews are highly trained. Use of poorer quality crew and older, less well‐maintained vessels will significantly increase insurance costs paid by users, particularly given that Australian vessels undertake longer voyages in often severe conditions. Needless
to say, the risk of environmental damage will also be increased.

The Great Barrier Reef, along the north eastern coast of Australia, is one of the great world heritage natural assets—not just for Australia but for the world. It is always at risk from a major marine disaster such as an oil tanker going down. We have seen this happen in the last 30 years, right back to the 1960s. We saw the
Torrey Canyon
disaster off the south coast of England and the environmental damage it did. So we are under no illusions that Australia is always at risk, in environmental terms, of a marine disaster.

The decimation of the industry is likely to have a number of detrimental effects in other areas: marine insurance, stevedoring, towage, pilotage, development and supply of shipping technology, and ship management repair and maintenance. Australia will also lose vital information on the state of international shipping markets. Port and other maritime regulatory authorities will have a greatly reduced pool of skilled labour to draw on. This may affect not only the provision of harbour masters and ship control officers but also safety, investigation and emergency personnel in state departments.

Most countries, be they OECD countries or otherwise, provide fiscal assistance to their national fleets. I think that is the point that I made in my remarks on the bounty. Most OECD countries provide fiscal assistance to the national fleets. They understand the national interest at stake in having their own national fleet. They also understand the importance of not being in a closed market but being in the marketplace, competing to build up the skill levels of staff and management as well as seafarers and so on. All of this is seen in most countries in the OECD as a national interest issue. Unfortunately, this new coalition government does not have the same view.

The fiscal assistance to these national fleets in other countries includes depreciation allowances, concessional tax rates, and concessional loans and subsidies. As such, the abolition of assistance proposed would not create a level playing field for Australian shipping in the global market but rather place
the industry in a less competitive position. This government, with this legislation, wants our shipping fleet to be less competitive because most other OECD countries, our competitors, do provide assistance that I have just outlined.

Australian ship owners and workers have made significant gains in terms of productivity and competitiveness in the last decade. Since 1989, over $2 billion has been committed to investment in ships, with the result that the Australian fleet is half the age of the world fleet. Manning levels on Australian international ships have fallen from an average of 31.6 in 1986 to 18.4 in 1995, which the minister, in his second reading speech, conceded are now consistent with international standards.

Industrial disputes hit their lowest level in a decade in 1992-1993, when only 23 ship days were lost due to crew disputes. It is not right to now attack this industry that has made such progress halfway through a restructuring process merely to satisfy the government's hatred of the Maritime Union of Australia. Clearly, the underlying reason these two bills have been brought in is the opposition's ideological obsession against the maritime workers of this country.

Yet over the decade that union has agreed, in discussion with government and with the owners, to reduce the manning levels from 31.6 to 18.4—nearly half the number. There are certainly ongoing discussions. The union recognises that levels could go even lower. It wants to do it in a planned way. But this government, for ideological reasons to prove a point—and this is almost a theology on its part—has consistently attacked Australian seafarers.

You will remember that, when they were previously in government, the coalition did nothing to deal with the issue of updating the fleet and getting higher productivity. They just carried out a no‐action program, other than to make, from time to time, remarks attacking the workers in the industry.

The early withdrawal of the capital grant will have a number of specific effects. Shipowners will now have less incentive to invest in new ships and technology. As a result, the
fleet will age, which will increase costs which must ultimately be passed on to users. Further increases in capital productivity, and hence manning levels, will be less likely as the cost of new vessels increases.

Repealing the grant paid to international trading vessels will have a number of effects. It will provide an incentive for Australian vessels to switch from international to coastal operations, so placing pressure on the `invisibles' deficit, the current account deficit. This will occur as a result of increasing the cost of international traders relative to coastal ones.

There are the examples of companies which, as a result of the introduction of this bill, have reorganised their fleet schedules to increase export earnings. Is that what we should be about? Of course it is. This is a result of the legislation which we previously introduced; we are improving our export earnings. However, for ideological reasons, the government is taking action mainly to have a go at the marine workers, the seafarers. In having a go at them, it is actually shooting itself in the foot and weakening our ability to reduce the current account deficit.

Australian ship owners will be placed at a competitive disadvantage in relation to ships registered in other countries where there are generous tax concessions and also specifically in relation to ships registered in tax havens. So there we have it. Instead of having an industry with its confidence growing, one that can be competitive with this modest assistance from the Australian government, we will be putting ourselves at a distinct disadvantage to most of our OECD competitors. We will be tilting the playing field against ourselves.

This government displays a classical, own‐goal attitude. It wants to kick a goal against our shipping industry when everybody would say it is in our national interest to have the capacity for an up‐to‐date maritime merchant fleet operating around the world. To the opposition, it is very strange indeed that one of the first bills this government is trying to put through hits on the head the development of a modern maritime fleet in Australia. As a result, we oppose this legislation. I will indicate in this second reading debate that we
will support the government amendment which, as we understand it, will now have the effect of allowing the three vessels under construction, that would not previously have received the grant, to receive it. When this bill was proposed, that was the most preposterous suggestion of all: that three vessels—already under construction—would not be eligible for the grant. The government has seen the light of day and so we will support its amendment in that area.

We will not support the Democrats' amendment to establish a working party because, on the advice we have received, there has not been consultation with the various parties in the industry about how that working party would operate. We think you should support such a working party only where there has been proper consultation, and the players in the industry have agreed to it.

We support the Greens' amendment, a second reading one, calling on the government to pursue multilateral agreements to protect the industrial conditions of international seafarers and to enforce safety standards. It would also put in place a comprehensive international compensation regime for damage to the marine environment, with a requirement to report to the Senate once a year on progress. We support that Greens' amendment.

In supporting the amendments, we want to say that we do not support this bill. We believe it is an indication that this government does not have a clear and comprehensive industry policy. Industry and business leaders are already complaining publicly and loudly about this government's lack of vision in regard to our manufacturing and transport industries. In this case, our international shipping industry is going to go backwards because of an ideological position—or an ideological aversion—this government has towards the seafarers of this country, particularly the workers who have made major sacrifices to improving this industry over the last decade in a very cooperative way.
