speech.speaker: Murray, Sen Andrew

talk.start.para: —The Shipping Grants Legislation Bill 1996 seeks to commence the dismantling of the cooperative approach to maritime reform, which has seen disputation fall significantly and productivity rise significantly in the Australian maritime industry over the past decade. It seeks to target two measures, both of which were to the benefit of the industry, introduced by the previous government. The first is the seven per cent capital investment allowance for new ships, which was first introduced in 1987 and has since been extended twice. The second is the rebate for employers of seafarers in respect of PAYE tax remittances for their employees. This measure was part of the last set of maritime reform legislation introduced in 1994 and mirrors international practice by many other developed countries. The government estimates that the repeal of the capital grants will save $12 million while the repeal of the tax rebate will save $40 million over four years, or $10 million per year. Incidentally, there is a conflict between the government's budget papers and the EM on that matter.

speech.para:
The bill was tabled in May and sent to the Senate Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Committee for report. The committee
heard evidence from three major companies—BHP, Shell and Mackay Sugar Cooperative—who were midway through major shipbuilding exercises and were caught up by the premature termination of the capital grants. After public exposure and intense lobbying, the government has apparently revised its position. I understand that it will be moving amendments to allow those three ships to retain access to grants provided that they are delivered before 1 July next year. I do not have those amendments before me.

The Australian Democrats will be supporting those proposed government amendments on capital grants. If those amendments do not materialise, we will oppose the early cessation of the capital grants scheme. We believe that the capital grants scheme has played a significant role in updating and modernising the Australian shipping fleet. More modern vessels have encouraged the reduction of shipping crew ratios, which have fallen from 36 to 18 per vessel over the last decade.

We now have internationally competitive crewing ratios, and that is a credit to the unions, shipowners and seafarers. Australian crewing levels are now lower than the world average crew size of 23.8 and the OECD average of 22. Obviously, more may need to be done. I note that the MUA has been resisting attempts by some shipowners to take crewing ratios lower, even when it is safe to do so.

It is appropriate that we look at whether industrial assistance programs are still needed. As you know from my minority report tabled yesterday, the Australian Democrats will oppose the early abolition of the shipbuilders bounty. With regard to this issue, between 1988 and 1994, 36 additional and replacement vessels were added into the Australian fleet, representing a turnover of 45 per cent of the fleet and reducing the age of the Australian fleet to well below the world average.

Clearly, the ships capital grants scheme is one program that has achieved its purpose. It has done a good job for the Australian fleet. It can now be terminated, in our view. With the amendment that the government has
agreed to which protects those in transition through the scheme, we will support its abolition.

The repeal of the International Shipping (Australian‐resident Seafarers) Grants Act 1995 and, with it, the rebate of PAYE taxes paid by Australian resident seafarers on ships that operate 50 per cent or more of their time in international trade is another matter. The 1995 act was an important and essential policy change, which we supported at the time. We thought it was appropriate then, and we think it is appropriate now. The government claims that that rebate was some sort of handout from a captive Labor government to the MUA to keep them quiet over the ANL sale. That is what is implied in the second reading speech. That is not how we saw it then, and it is not how we see it now. It is our view that the PAYE measure is a revenue exercise and has nothing to do with that spurious argument.

This measure was one of several recommended by the Shipping Industry Reform Authority in August 1994. The report noted that 12 out of the 25 OECD countries make concessions for the tax treatment of national seafarers on international routes. Many shipowners from other countries are able to avoid the payment of tax altogether by permitting the offshore movement of vessels and crew employment. The report concluded:
Given the significance of this cost, it is considered essential that Australian seafarers in the international trades be treated similarly.

In short, without this measure, Australian ships will not be competitive against the ships of other OECD countries let alone flags of convenience ships. This point was clearly made in submissions from the Australian Shipowners Association to the Senate committee.

Of course, that does not mean that Australia obtains no tax revenue from Australian ships and seafarers. As Australian residents, seafarers are obviously spending in this country, as the shipowners are running their administration and are paying company tax and all the other taxes in this country. If the shipping industry were to disappear completely because it was uncompetitive, Treasury would lose
this much larger pool of revenue. I draw to your attention that, once again, this government has failed to do a cost‐benefit analysis and any kind of modelling analysis or sensitivity analysis over getting rid of this.

This is obviously the assessment made by the other 12 OECD countries that now provide full or partial rebates on seafarers' PAYE taxes. Once again, the principle is obvious. Australia must not act in isolation of its competitors. Short-term deficit reduction measures have to be weighed against greater medium‐ and long-term harm to a vital industry. I say to you again that you have not done a cost‐benefit analysis.

I note in passing that the authority also pointed to the importance of vigilant port control inspections of ships from flags of convenience states to ensure that competition is on a fair basis on routes to and from Australia. The Australian Maritime Safety Authority has considerably increased its inspection activity since 1991. It is now inspecting over 2,700 ships per year, with 10 per cent being referred for irregularities and further safety repairs.

The 1994 maritime reform package, which included the PAYE initiative, also required the shipowners and the maritime unions to negotiate savings that would deliver efficiency improvements roughly equivalent in value to the PAYE measure, which was about $19 million per annum. The result, the maritime industry restructuring agreement, has seen a quantum shift from industry awards to enterprise agreements, the cessation of industry training of ratings—a measure itself worth $190 million a year—increased flexibility and cooperation in the engagement system, and a new system of dealing with ratings who were the subject of disciplinary action. Contrary to the ideological ravings—and they are ravings sometimes—of some of those in the government and elsewhere, these have been significant achievements, a point recognised by both unions and employers. But, clearly, more needs to be done. International trade does not stand still and nor should maritime reform and change in the maritime industry.

The way forward in our view is to encourage workers, their unions and their employers
to continue working constructively together. Under the previous government, a new era of reconciliation was initiated, and that should continue. The pace of reform might not be as fast as the ideologues in government would like, but it is achieving results. Confrontation will not get us there; consultation and negotiation will.

I believe that access to the PAYE rebate should continue to be tied to continuing reform. The employers and the unions both claim good progress to date. Both sectors, particularly the employers, want to see more progress. The government disagrees that there is good progress. I accept the opinion of those more directly affected, namely the unions and the employers.

The 1994 SIRA report had a wide range of other measures which it recommended to both unions and employers. Progress in some of these has been far too slow. In the committee stage, I will be proposing an amendment to continue this process by the establishment, under the International Shipping (Australian‐resident Seafarers) Grants Act, of a process to continue the reform work. I have circulated that amendment before you, and you should note that I have withdrawn the previous amendment. That working party will be required to report back to parliament on its progress. If progress is not satisfactory, then we as the Australian Democrats will review our position on the PAYE rebate.

The Democrats are satisfied that the parties are abiding by the commitment that they gave in 1994 when the rebate was introduced. While progress is being made on maritime reform, parliament should be prepared to underwrite that progress by ensuring that our tax system is internationally competitive in seafaring routes. This PAYE grant is about competitiveness, and that is where the focus should be.

speech.speaker: Margetts, Sen Dee

talk.start.para:
—The explanatory memorandum of this bill is a sad testimony of the government's approach. It includes a financial impact statement showing how much the government will save but gives no consideration at all to the impact on people, either
Australian seafarers or non‐Australian seafarers.

speech.para: The situation with seafarers is one of the worst and most shameful examples of the action of international competition and the race for the bottom. Seafarers have virtually no protection since they operate in international waters. While there are many national awards specifying wages and conditions, there are few requirements for any ship, regardless of the country of registration, to provide minimum wages or conditions to all seafarers, regardless of nationality. Under such a situation, the economic imperative to reduce costs and increase profit margins will virtually force shipping companies to employ the cheapest possible crews.

If any nation has award standards for its seafarers on international ships, either national flag or foreign flag vessels, then the response of shipping companies is almost certain: to hire crews from nations without such conditions. There are extreme impacts of hiring crews from nations which do not offer even nominal protection for such workers—workers who operate in international waters—when no nation takes an interest in their treatment and when their foreign status as employees of a foreign vessel and/or the status of their agreement on wages and conditions is seen as a commercial matter outside the ambit of national law or concern.

The major impacts are that such workers have effectively no rights at all and no legal framework whatever to protect their interests. They are entirely at the mercy of shipowners. Virtually no nation will let such a crew disembark on any but the most temporary basis. No claim for asylum or relief of mistreatment is generally recognised.

The result at this point, which is fairly well documented, is that horrific abuses are perpetrated against vulnerable seafarers. There are many examples of crews not being paid. They may be mistreated, denied food or denied adequate food. They may be beaten, raped or otherwise physically abused. They are, sometimes, killed.

At sea, the only power is the captain of the vessel. The captain and his officers, who are the perpetrators of the abuses, are the only
keepers of official records. All power and all appeal is in the hands of the perpetrators of abuse. At the very least, an outcome is understaffing, with the consequent loss of safety for not only the ship but also other ships and the environment.

One of the few things that prevent Australian flag ships from the pressure to behave in the same manner or absorb the competitive penalties from behaving more responsibly is the act which this bill seeks to repeal—the International Shipping (Australian‐resident Seafarers) Grants Act. These grants for seafarers recognise that providing crew conditions and staffing levels adequate for safety and ship maintenance, and the pressure of paying seafarers their wages, costs money. Until there are international standards for seafarers, and they are enforced generally on a multinational basis—the ILO standards exist but are rarely enforced—national action is the only alternative. National action needs to go beyond imposing costs on Australian industry and provide some measure to reduce the competitive penalty of acting responsibly.

In our deregulated world, the only means to do this is by some measure of support for those who do act responsibly and in accordance with Australian standards. An alternative that should be looked at is to put a fee or charge on all incoming ships for inspection as to conditions and treatment of crew, payment of wages and whether the staff levels are, in fact, sufficient to run the ship safely. This would be parallel to physical inspection of ships for safety.

It is unconscionable to simply ignore what are effectively human rights abuses or an inability for ships which enter our ports to operate safely. If conditions were adequate by Australian standards, a large portion of the fee could be refunded. Where they were not, action might be taken, but at least the major part of the fee would be retained to offset an ongoing support for Australian crew.

The safety issue, aside from the physical maintenance of ships, is significant. Commercial ships on automatic pilots can easily run over small ships, aside from their inability to actually see physical signs of danger, or water breaking on rocks or reefs. Where crew levels
are so low that there are only one or two people on watch at night, and where those people may occasionally go for a break or coffee while the ship sails under automatic pilot, or even where the ship sails under automatic pilot with an officer on deck, or where there are only one or two people on the deck, depth sounders, radar and other equipment may not be monitoring regularly and, in any case, may not give warning of something, even a large yacht with a wooden or non‐aluminium mast and spars, or a rock, or a suddenly arising reef. These, of course, can be seen or heard from the deck if there are a few crew members on deck watch.

Australia has seen ships run aground in the last few years. Environmental problems are not confined to tankers. Other ships may leak fuel and have cargoes that represent environmental hazards. The
Sanko Harvest
, which ran aground in February 1991 off Esperance on the south coast of Western Australia, was carrying fertiliser, which, in such concentrations, can have a devastating effect on reefs and marine coastal ecologies.

Shipping grants is one of the other issues here. They are for new or extensively modified ships to assist with equipment, allowing a safe reduction of crew. Much of this is automated equipment, allowing a worker to safely work alone, or nearly alone. In the existing legislation, the shipping grants were intended to be phased out in 1997. This cuts it out a year earlier, but consequences for industry of having the time lines changed are economically significant. Plans and contracts for construction of major ships is a lengthy process. Changing funding frameworks with little warning creates problems. The minority report of the legislative committee highlights this.

The government amendments also recognise this, but do not address the real problem, which is that plans and arrangements were made several years ago on the basis that the grants would run throughout the 1996‐97 financial year, rather than stopping approximately six months ago. This depends on the quality of the equipment, but also provides little safety margin for equipment failure, if
crews are reduced on the assumption that technology makes it safe to do so.

Where automation is in the form of alarms on depth sounders or radar, the assumption is not only that the machine is on and working, but that it is capable of picking up images. Wooden ships with non‐aluminium spars are notoriously bad radar targets. A crew member on watch may alert the helm and narrowly avert an accident. An alarm that does not see the ship will not.

I have been given instructions by one of my staffers, Dhanu, that in his personal experience freighters and tankers frequently go on autopilot and do not detect something that could be a 95‐foot, three‐masted, aluminium sparred ship of substantial size—he was talking about something of 120 tonnes. During three years sailing, he said he just avoided collision at least five times, under clear weather conditions and in spite of hailing by voice, bells, signal lights and radio on emergency frequencies. In one instance, they narrowly averted collision with a large tanker which passed by at speed within 10 feet of them. This was in the Straits of Malacca, a heavily travelled, narrow, busy seaway where it would be expected that extra attention should be given due to the large number of risks and frequency of accidents.

In the last 10 years, at least 30 ships have had accidents on the Great Barrier Reef which were subject to investigations. Of those, approximately two‐thirds were groundings. In many cases, lack of adequate attention is implicit. The other third were collisions where lack of attention—direct, watchful, human attention—was nearly always a factor. About one‐quarter of these ships were Australian flag vessels. Thirty‐three had pilots on board, indicating either lack of care or a possible crew related inability to respond to a developing situation.

In the last 10 years, there have been a total of 97 accidents in Australian waters which were subject to investigations. Of those, 37, or roughly one‐third, were groundings; 21, or about one‐quarter, were collisions; 11, all in the last five years, were fatalities or injuries; 13 were where a ship foundered; 10 were fires; four, including the
Kirki
, were major
structural failures; one was a berthing incident; and there were 32 incidents involving Australian ships with Australian crews.

The government amendments recognise the basic truth that, where an agreement has already been made to construct a ship, it is simply unfair to alter the economic conditions under which such an agreement was made. Any agreement covered by the government amendments would have been made in the expectation that the shipping grants would continue until the end of June 1997. The Senate has virtually always voted to remedy a situation where executive government seeks to impose costs on industries, where there has been an extensive forward commercial arrangement, through legislative change of the conditions under which such arrangements were made.

We have looked at the Democrats second reading amendments, but they may be a way of allowing the indefensible. Without the Democrats' support, this bill may have died, although, of course, I am in no way speaking for the other Independent senators. I am not sure what will be achieved by the seeking of a statutory working party, because these committees almost universally push for economic deregulation and the nature of the committees is, of course, very important. The terms of reference of the working party do still reflect a rationalist approach and are intended to pursue the competitive agenda. This would work against the situation of seafarers and is likely to work against both human and environmental safety. The terms of reference may allow the bill to get support.

—Is that 273?
—Yes, about the working party.
—Senator Margetts, have you acknowledged the problem?
—Yes, I am greatly relieved. I move:

(a)
calls upon the Government to pursue multilateral agreements in all possible international fora to:

(i)

(ii)

(iii)

speech.para: It is impossible to regulate without agreed international standards. Regulation must be for both workers'—human rights—and environmental protection. Nations must have the moral and internationally recognised legal duty and right to enforce these international standards equally.

The need for a comprehensive environmental liability regime was agreed to by the Senate in relation to a motion I put in 1993. We reiterate that need. If I had my druthers, I would see that Australia does what the United States does and imposes its own liability regime. That is simply being able to clearly work out who is responsible and knowing that there is a means of meeting financial and other costs should such a disaster occur.

break.para: That is not the case in Australia at the moment. There are limited regimes for bonds in the shipping industry. But there is no comprehensive liability regime, and the reason for that is often cited as the need to be internationally competitive. I often think that if any industry benefits from utilising flag of convenience or lower standards of shipping, perhaps the outcome should be that those particular industries or companies end up bearing part of the cost if their choice to reduce the standard of shipping results in a dreadful maritime disaster. A liability regime is a much more sensible way to go.

We reiterate that need and add the need for comprehensive liability relating to the cost of ensuring that the basic human rights of seafarers are protected. This must include legal costs and the cost of the repatriation of seafarers fleeing the conditions on their ships. Australian governments are already having to deal with such cases.

The Senate, in passing such amendment, has the right to ask for a report of progress. This was done in 1993 with support from the then government. As yet, I am still unclear as to what the details of that report were.

speech.speaker: Brown, Sen Bob

talk.start.para: —I concur with the submission just made by Senator Margetts of the Greens (WA) and will be supporting the amendment that she has put forward relating to the Shipping Grants Legislation Bill. I also concur with the Australian Labor Party's comments on this earlier in the day. As a Tasmanian, I have a particular interest in the bounty because it affects Incat, which is a large modern industrial operation by Tasmanian standards, if not by world standards. It employs over 1,000 people and has a very vigorous training program for skilling people into the work force at a time when this government is removing many training programs which would otherwise skill people.

speech.para:
We have the worst unemployment situation, the lowest per capita income and arguably the worst financial situation of any of the states. So, whilst it might seem unusual for me as a Green to be standing here in defence of a major industry in Tasmania—we get pilloried for not doing so—the reality is that this
industry is Tasmanian home‐grown. It is not like the big old industries dependent on secret subsidised hydro-electric contracts, on subsidised demolition of forests or on the digging up of mines—all of which seem to have their headquarters on the mainland and disburse their profits immediately out of the state. It does have a much richer flow-on benefit to Tasmania's economy and its social wellbeing in general.

What has been talked about here is the government penny‐pinching to the point of reneging by one year on a bounty scheme which is very important to Bob Clifford's operation and to the welfare of this industry. Tasmania has, along with Western Australia, taken a world lead in the production of high‐speed catamaran shipping, which is a very vigorous industry in this day of much altered shipping profile around the world. We know that the allegiance of shipbuilders has its limitations, that they are looking at places like China to expand in the future or to transfer operations if the going gets too tough in Australia. We know that when it comes to the payment of labour and so on we simply cannot compete with places like China.

It is a bit of a rough end of the stick for this government to suddenly cut the bounty, a year before it was due to be phased out, on this shipbuilding operation in Tasmania. It will mean a 15 per cent increase in price on the average ship coming out of that shipbuilding facility in Tasmania. At the moment, one catamaran—80 metres or more in length—comes out of the slips every eight or 10 weeks. The price of those goes up by 15 per cent, or $5 million. It makes it much more difficult to sell them on the world market where there is competition, from European shipbuilders in particular. So it does make a real difference, particularly when the companies built the past government's commitment on this into their future sales program.

para.break: I will be voting against this legislation. I will be voting for the interests of this bright spot in the Tasmanian economic profile. Let me say straight off that I do not see eye to eye with Bob Clifford on many things. I have not heard him contributing very much to the defence of Tasmania's environmental well being, the major natural asset of the island these days in generating jobs and business. I do not think he is particularly forward in defending Green ideals.

speech.para: But that is not what this debate is about. It is about the livelihood of more than a thousand Tasmanians and their dependants. That is what I am standing in defence of. That is why I find it very difficult—I cannot refer to you, Mr Acting Deputy President Watson—to understand why Tasmanian representatives opposite are not standing and defending the Tasmanian interest against this piece of legislation. If they were, this legislation would not get through. The second component of this is—

talk.start.para: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. It is to do with relevance. The legislation that Senator Brown is referring to is a separate piece of legislation. There are issues that have some similarities. However, the bounties that are delivered to people such as Bob Clifford of mInCat in Tasmania and Austal Ships and Oceanfast in Western Australia relate to a different piece of legislation and are not actually relevant to this piece of legislation. That is for the information of the Senate. There is a standing order on relevance.

—Yes, thank you. I thank the government spokesperson for that because what I have just said now gives breathing space to the Tasmanian senators opposite to really have more time to consider changing their minds as far as the bounty is concerned. So it has been a very constructive little session and I feel really chuffed about having been able to send that message across the Senate.

para.break: The subsidy that goes to seafarers in Australian waters is being cut by this piece of legislation. It is a subsidy that is roughly equivalent to reimbursing the employers with the amount that their employees are taxed, as far as taxation is concerned. It is a pretty vital subsidy because it ensures that we have maximum opportunity to employ Australian sea farers and to keep Australian interest in shipping around our coasts and elsewhere.

speech.para: A fortnight ago the workplace relations bill went through this place. That legislation cut the ability of maritime unions to come to the defence of people who float into Australian ports on ships of shame that are in appalling conditions and owned under flags of convenience elsewhere. We know that those conditions range from subsistence levels on board ships and people not being paid for months or even years on end to the extraordinary physical abuse of seafarers to the point where some who have stuck up for their rights have disappeared overboard overnight—an appalling situation.

The government's legislation, supported by the Australian Democrats as it was, on that occasion cut the muscle of unions in Australia to go to the defence of these unfortunate seafarers coming into our waters. This piece of legislation cuts the muscle of employers of seafarers in Australia to be able to maximise their opportunity to keep Australians in those jobs under standards that we would accept as being reasonable in this day and age.

There is no doubt that the employment levels on shipping around Australia have dropped to internationally acceptable levels. There is no doubt that the standards of work conditions of Australian seafarers are better than those of a great number of ships floating into our ports. There is no doubt that in the absence of international arrangements we are doing the right thing by subsidising and fostering seafarers' welfare through the existing legislation.

I oppose a change to that legislation which is simply going to flow on to an increase of the number of ships of shame coming into our ports, the advantage that they have and the subsistence conditions that they allow people to work under. At the same time, that change will cut out the potential to employ Australians to work the ships on our coastline under proper conditions.

Finally, I would like to reiterate what Senator Schacht said this morning in this place. In relation to the environment and the economy, you would think that the government would back shipping around Australia.
Whichever way you look at it, it is a cheaper form of transport for cargo. But, environmentally, in terms of contributions to greenhouse gases, as Senator Schacht said, it is a far superior way of transporting cargo than rail, which in turn is a far superior method than road transport.

What is this government doing? It is subsidising road transport to the teeth, it is removing government assistance to rail and it is abolishing government assistance to sea transport. For a government that beats its chest about having a concern for the environment, it is going exactly the wrong way. For those reasons, I oppose the legislation and I will be supporting the Greens amendments.

talk.start.para: —The government amendment to this bill was originally provided in the form of a request for amendment. This reflected one of the theories put forward by the government drafters that an amendment which modifies a reduction in expenditure requires a request.

interject.para: This is not, however, the practice followed by the Senate in the past. A request has been required only if the amendment would add to expenditure by comparison with the status quo. Where a bill would reduce expenditure and an amendment would limit the reduction, but not increase expenditure under the status quo, such an amount has been treated as not requiring a request. The rationale for this is that the relevant constitutional provision, the third paragraph of section 53, refers to an amendment which would increase a proposed charge or burden on the people and clearly does not relate to an amendment which merely limits a proposed reduction of existing expenditure.

The Senate has not accepted the contrary theory of the government drafters. The application and interpretation of the constitutional provision was recently reported on by the Procedure Committee. Under the recommendations of the committee, this amendment would not be a request. It should be noted that the amendment would also not be a request under the recommendations of the House of Representatives committee which considered the application of section 53. The proposed request for amendment has therefore been treated as an amendment.

It did so by dishonouring undertakings that had been previously given for the construction of these three vessels.

speech.para: When the three companies—BHP, Shell and Mackay Sugar—let the contracts to their foreign yards in the Netherlands and in the Republic of Korea for these vessels, they let them on the understanding that the ships capital grants scheme would apply. The basis on which they could afford those contracts in the first place was that that provision would stand. What the government proposed by its original bill was to dishonour those contracts and visit on those three companies a significant financial penalty. It did so in the name of budget savings.

On this occasion we have seen internal considerations within the coalition. My colleague Senator Schacht has referred to the role of the National Party in this. Certainly, press reports would strongly support what Senator Schacht has said. I am not entirely sure whether Senator Boswell was the leader of the charge, but certainly press reports would support the role of the National Party in this.

On this occasion, the government now moves to correct a wrong they would have inflicted on this industry. The sad truth is that
this is not the only area in which the excessive zeal in the eternal hunt for savings by Treasury is visiting a wrong on industry. There are a number of other areas. Those bills are on the
Notice Paper
—the bounties legislation bill, Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) and a number of other bills which are in the pipeline and in which the same principle of `don't worry about the punishment meted out to industry; just take the savings when you can' is being applied. I would hope that the government, in being sensible on this matter, would exhibit the same degree of commonsense on the other bills as well.

In one sense this principle is meting out a financial penalty on Australian industry, but in a very real sense it is taking jobs off Australians. The interesting thing here is, of course, that the government is going to pay a subsidy for the construction of ships to be built in foreign shipyards. In the Bounty Legislation Amendment Bill 1996, the government is removing a payment for ships constructed in Australian shipyards. While I strongly support the amendment that is being put to the government; nonetheless, a bill that is in the list will penalise Australian shipbuilders while this amendment will advantage foreign shipbuilders. I just think there is something rotten in the state of industry policy when that type of situation applies.

I am pleased that on this occasion the Senate committee's role in uncovering what was a serious penalty to be imposed on Australian industry worked and that the committee played an important part in changing the government's mind. I hope that remains true and I hope the principle the government is adopting in this amendment, which we support, it will adopt when those other pieces of legislation come before this Senate. If it does not, we will certainly remind the government of it. Certainly, I expect that industry will too because, as I have said, jobs are at risk. Those jobs are in Tasmania, Western Australia and South Australia in the shipbuilding industry. In this case, these jobs are in the Netherlands and in South Korea. I support the amendment.

debate.title: VOCATIONAL EDUCATION AND TRAINING FUNDING AMENDMENT BILL 1996

proctext.para:
Debate resumed from 17 October, on motion by
Senator Campbell
:
That this bill be now read a second time.

speech.speaker: Carr, Sen Kim

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak on behalf of the opposition. This is a very flimsy bill. There are three pages in total, and that is symbolic of this government's commitment to vocational education and training. It is practically non‐existent. We should not be surprised by this, nor should we be fooled by it because the impact of this bill is quite dramatic. Those three pages reflect the impact of two budget decisions which will fall heavily on the TAFE sector: the elimination of the five per cent real growth provided by the previous Labor government and the imposition of a five per cent efficiency dividend on TAFE funding.

speech.para: This bill amends the Vocational Education and Training Funding Act 1992, which provides the bulk of funding for vocational education, to increase funding by $13.4 million in the first year, 1996, but to reduce it by $58.6 million in 1997. The change for 1996 simply reflects the impact of price changes. However, the adjustment for 1997 reflects the net impact of the budget decisions to which I have referred.

Examination of this legislation gives us a clearer picture of what the government really has in mind for vocational education and training. Stripped of the rhetoric, we notice that the two budget measures reflected in this bill cut vocational education funding by $91 million and $66 million respectively over the four years of the forward estimates. This,
together with other savings measures such as the cuts to the Australian National Training Authority, well and truly exceeds the additional funding available through the so‐called modern Australian apprenticeship and training system. In addition to that, massive cuts are being made to labour market programs which will have a major impact on the TAFE colleges, not to mention the impact on the chances of unemployed people acquiring the necessary skills to obtain a job.

Before the election, we heard from the coalition endless assurances about the future of TAFE. We were told that under the coalition's policy, as detailed by statements made in its schools and TAFE policy document, a Howard government would:
. . . continue to support a strong and effective TAFE sector, that is, the publicly funded network of TAFE institutions and the thousands of students and teachers involved in the system.
The same document notes this commitment:
. . . ensure that the network of TAFE institutions, especially in rural areas and regional centres, will not be undermined.
Further, it states that a coalition government would do this:
. . . in conjunction with the States and Territories develop a National Plan for TAFE.

It does not take long to work out the difference an election makes. What news did the budget bring for TAFE? The news was almost uniformly bad. TAFE is being expected to absorb an even bigger efficiency dividend than other recipients of Commonwealth own purpose outlays and specific purpose payments. The burden on TAFE is five per cent from the first year, while the general impost is three per cent in the first year and an additional one per cent applied cumulatively for each succeeding year.

The result of this funding cut will be felt both in recurrent and capital activities. It is likely that funds made available to ANTA for national projects will be halved, while interstate cooperation projects will cease altogether. National projects include research and evaluation, training, market development, some equity measures and curriculum development.

break.para: The rationale for all these changes to interstate cooperative projects and various other things is that they ought to be funded under bilateral agreements between the states. Regardless of whether it can be argued that there is no justification for special funding for projects which cross state borders, it is nevertheless possible, even probable, that alternative funding will not be found for some projects and that some worthwhile activities will cease.

The wide area learning project, for example, which is a joint New South Wales-Queensland venture, involves the delivery of services to isolated and disadvantaged communities with little or no previous access to further education and training. The Wali Palyantjaku Building Houses project in South Australia provides training in the building industry for Aboriginal communities living in remote areas. It is another example of a project the funding for which will stop altogether. There will also be cuts in capital funding, with a significant fall from $227.644 million in 1996 to $200 million in 1997. This is the government's so‐called commitment to TAFE at work at the grassroots level.

This government would have us believe that it has embarked on a revolutionary form of vocational education and that not one useful initiative happened before 2 March 1996. It is very interesting to note that the minister has yet again provided the usual divergence. He put out a press release today repackaging all the budget measures in such a way as to make it appear that there is something new. It was a very transparent device to take public attention away from the discussion in the Senate here today. The same pattern has emerged time and again.

The reality is that education was a high priority under Labor during the entire 13 years of Labor government. Major policy development in vocational education and training has taken place, particularly since 1990, when the Commonwealth moved towards assuming a greater role in ensuring the coordinated development of our national vocational education and training schemes. Labor's policy development and national leadership were underpinned by the provision
of sufficient funds to meet the stated goals. Labor put its money where its mouth was. Labor committed $1.65 billion in growth funds to the VET sector between 1992 and 1997. That was designed to generate an additional 792,000 places in vocational education and training. During its period in office, the Labor government provided a 56 per cent real increase in funding for TAFE and other forms of vocational education and training.

At the time of the change of government, a range of activities was already under way. There was a broad national framework and agreement on how the Australian vocational training system should be progressed. A major body of work was being undertaken under the auspices of ANTA to develop courses and curricula to make them consistent with Australian vocational training scheme principles. It was about developing a competency base and a more flexible set of arrangements so that courses could be more flexibly delivered in contexts other than the traditional college environment.

Contrary to what the current government would have us believe, the needs of schools in the provision of vocational education received a significant amount of attention. The Labor government committed $38 million to the Australian Student Traineeship Foundation, which was designed to support initiatives to provide vocational education and work experience for school students. The jobs pathway guarantee was designed to assist young people's transition from school to work. On the basis of these programs and others, the number of schools with year 12 retention rates grew to well over 70 per cent. Most of these students were not necessarily destined for university. These schools have an important role to play in the delivery of vocational education. We support the proposal to earmark $20 million per year in ANTA funds for use by schools.

We are also supportive of moves to try to rationalise the whole system of course recognition and the relationship of course with competency standards developed by the national training bodies, or so-called ITABS. It is envisaged that the ITABS will have a
greater role not only in the development of standards but also in other areas of curriculum development.

A major potential problem with the government's approach, however, lies in its faith in the user‐choice concept. This is the market based approach rearing its ugly head yet again. It is based on the notion that training will be far more relevant if it is more closely attuned to industry needs. When taken too far, however, with industry too much in charge of the direction, we could end up with training that is specific to particular firms. Our vocational education and training system must retain the capacity to provide broad generic competencies that have application across a range of jobs and pathways. It should ensure that workers have skills that are transferable between jobs and not specific to any one job or, more especially, any one firm.

We will be watching the development of the policy framework to ensure that suitable safeguards prevent a situation where public funds provided for vocational education and training end up being just another kind of industry subsidy. That is an important issue, particularly as firms wind back their commitment to training their employees.

I would also like to address the way in which the massive cuts to labour market programs have been interacting with other vocational education and training. A report in the
Sydney Morning Herald
of 7 October 1996 quoted the New South Wales Minister for Education and Training as saying:

TAFE institutes have estimated the cuts to labour market programs over the next four years will cost each of them between $2 million and $6 million this financial year, and put at risk 340 full-time teaching positions . . .
Institutes in Sydney's west, where about 41 labour market programs were operating last year, would lose 914 student places, while institutes on the North Coast would lose 2777.

This demonstrates the utter foolishness of this government in being unable to properly fund our education system in the first place and then not provide the resources to give skills to people who are unlikely to find jobs without them. Such actions will flow on and themselves reduce job opportunities. The ALP
seeks to amend the motion for the second reading of this bill. I move:
At the end of the motion, add
", but the Senate:

(a)
is of the opinion that the vocational education and training system has an increasingly vital role in providing Australia's young people with skills appropriate to the changing workplace; and

(b)
condemns the Government:

para.tab:
(i)
for proposing substantial cuts in expenditure
which will hamper the vocational education and training sector in fulfilling this role; and

(ii)
for clearly failing to meet its election commitments to `continue to support a strong and effective TAFE sector' and to `ensure that the network of TAFE institutions, especially in rural areas and regional centres, will not be undermined'."

break.para: I might indicate that the opposition is truly very disturbed about the manner in which this government is pressing about with its educational policies. As with so many educational areas, the coalition seems intent upon winding back the Commonwealth's national leadership role.

As far as we are concerned, education had a much higher priority during the 13 years of Labor government than this government is prepared to acknowledge. This government has quite deliberately sought, through its budget policies, to reduce its financial commitment to the education and training sector within overall government initiatives. What we are seeing here is an attempt being made by this government to undermine the major policy development that was undertaken by Labor, particularly since 1990 when the Commonwealth moved towards assuming a much greater role in ensuring the coordinated development of our national vocational education and training scheme.

National leadership was what underpinned that policy development. It was underpinned further by a commitment of $1.65 billion in growth funds to the VET sector between 1992 and 1997. It was designed to generate an
additional 792,000 places in the vocational education and training sectors. During its period in government, Labor provided increases of some 56 per cent in the funding for vocational education and training in this country.

Such a vocation is fundamental to any government that seeks to maintain that it truly has national leadership aspirations in this area. Such a commitment and such a vision is not shared by this government, which makes Labor's record shine by comparison. I am very disappointed to see that this government has pursued such a reckless and negative policy in this area.

speech.speaker: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

talk.start.para: —The Australian Democrats echo many of the concerns that have been put forward today by the opposition and by Senator Carr. Indeed, it is rather a black week for education and training in this place. Earlier today we saw regressive changes to schools policy and funding passed by the Senate in the guise of more choice for parents, but what we are seeing in actuality is a continuation by this government of a shift of public funds to the private sector. I hope that is something we will not see in this place next week when we deliberate changes to the higher education sector which, again, represent cuts to education funding in this nation.

speech.para: The bill before us today amends the Vocational Education and Training Funding Act and it changes the legislated funding levels for ANTA in 1996, 1997 and 1998. I note that the increase in ANTA funding for 1996 is around $13.4 million. Of course, the Australian Democrats support that increase. It is apparently a supplement to the already legislated funding level and, I believe, reflects the increase in average weekly earnings and general inflationary pressures.

However, if we go on, we see that massive cuts will be taking place in ANTA's funding in 1997 and 1998. This government has decided to cut funding for ANTA in 1997 by close to $57.5 million. I note that this cut will pretty well be retained into the following year, 1998. Those cuts give us great reason to question this government's commitment to vocational education and training in this
country—to question its commitment to that sector, along with the other sectors such as primary and secondary education and higher education, which have already faced substantial funding cuts.

In fact, we find it very difficult to understand why this government would seek to make such cuts in 1997, virtually retaining this cut into 1998, when something like 8.7 per cent of Australians are still without a job. Cutting funding for vocational education and training at a time when we are confronted with high employment levels, with especially high levels of youth unemployment, in this country does not make sense.

As I understand it, the $57.5 million that will be cut from ANTA in 1997 consists basically of a five per cent efficiency dividend. That jargon is something we are hearing increasingly from this government—the notion of an efficiency dividend. It is being applied to TAFE and, of course, there is also the elimination of the five per cent growth in ANTA funding which was introduced by the previous government.

I should add that the Democrats played an important role in ensuring that the ANTA legislation was passed by the previous government in 1992. We promised then to hold them accountable when it came to ensuring that there were sufficient funds allocated for vocational education and training in this country. We intend to do the same with this government as well. I am only sorry, as I say, to see that they are cutting those funds.

What exactly does this government mean by an efficiency dividend? Is it really a genuine incentive and a viable tool for encouraging unruly departments to increase their productivity by perhaps increasing their efficiency levels, or is it just another nice piece of jargon to justify cutting public expenditure? In this case, I am not quite sure. That leads me to a further question. Is it reasonable to expect that five per cent worth of inefficiencies in the area of vocational education and training are actually there to be found and to be cut when, as I said, so many Australians are out of work?
Debate interrupted.
